ANTONY BEEVOR
My first novel, thank God, was never published. The typescript still lies at the bottom of some drawer box, its pages no doubt yellow and impregnated with dust I have not destroyed it because, even though ashamed, I am grateful to it Even the shame is a mixed feeling. I still feel slightly appalled that I could have dared to try to write a novel, having failed both my English
and history A levels at Winchester—a rare distinction which pleased neither parents nor school. Even with the advantage of hindsight, I can do no more than attribute this arbitrary decision to write to the utter ignorance and arrogance of youth. And yet if I had realised for a moment how utterly disqualified I was, life would have been sadly different. Careers can turn out to be such curious, unpredictable creatures, almost with a life of their own. As a child, I had Perthes disease, in which the hip bone goes soft. I was

DAVID ALMOND
Some folk thought I was mad when I quit my teaching job, sold my house and took up residence in a Norfolk commune. I was 30, and had published a handful of short stories in little magazines. The year that followed was idyllic. I helped to revive the commune's ancient overgrown garden, to renovate its ruined mansion. I wrote more stories. I fell in love. But as winter came, the commune started to founder on infighting and disillusionment. I left with my girlfriend and a woodturner and his gentle dog, and we rented a half-ruined Suffolk farmhouse. Months passed. The proceeds from the sale of my house declined. All of us were on the dole. We were very happy. I worked in a little timber-panelled room while hail pattered on the windows and the frosts came and went One day, almost in a dream, I wrote a story called Where Your Wings Were, which left me in tears. It grew out of the death of my sister in my childhood. It seemed so personal, so simple, so innocent. I could do nothing with it. I put it away. As the year turned, a letter arrived. It was from Peter Mortimer, the editor of the small northeastern Iron Press. He wanted to publish a collection of my stories. That evening, we cycled across the icy farm tracks to the pub in St James. We drank to literary celebrity and bestsellerdom, then we wobbled and skidded home again. Next day, I started to consider the contents of the book and didn't even think of finding a place for the story with the wings. It would take two years for the book to appear. By then, my money had gone. The book was called Sleepless Nights, it was 80 pages long, 500 copies were printed, and I was paid £50. But this little book, my first, helped to keep me calm and optimistic in the years that followed. I published more stories in more magazines. I had readers, even a handful of fans. I taught parttime. I wrote a novel, Seances, that was rejected by every UK publisher. One evening I found Where Your Wings Were in an old box file. The years had given it some distance from me. I rewrote it and sent it to Radio 4. It was broadcast The little story, left alone in the dark for so long, was proving to be some kind of seedbed. I rewrote it again, and a cluster of new, unbidden stories called Counting Stars grew out from it and from my childhood. When these were done, a new tale grew, about a boy with a poorly sister and about a creature with wings. When this book, Skellig, was published by Hodder, I was called a new writer. It was as-
MARGARET ATWOOD
The book appeared when I was 21. If it can be called appearing, that is. The location was Toronto, not at that time — to the naked eye — a hotbed of literary activity. They were still telling "the Toronto joke", then: first prize a week in Toronto, second prize two weeks in Toronto. If you were a young person who was serious about writing, you were expected to flee the place like a rat in the Dracula shipwreck scene, and that I duly did. But not before I had published this book. By "published", I mean that the book in question was sold in bookstores and reviewed in at least one periodical. It was not otherwise published. True to the Zeitgeist, I took a hand in the book-making: most young Canadian poets then
THEY MyST HAWE f HOUCWT 1 WAS A FOOL, A LOUA¥IC 01 - IU THE PAY - DIFFERENT
did something ofthe sort, as the few extant publishers were not clamouring for their wares. The book consisted of seven poems — short poems, luckily — for which I had won a university prize. It was printed in a cellar, on a flatbed press owned by a friend and colleague. Along with a fellow poet, I set the type. We had to do each poem separately, as there was a shortage of letter As. We ground out 300 copies of each poem, then folded the pages and stapled them together. The final edition was about 250, due to attrition. The cover was done with a lino-block: I carved the block, then set it into the flatbed. The stapled pages were glued into the cover with rubber cement — a mistake, because the glue dried out, as well as smelling odd. Then — how did I get the nerve? — I actually went around to various bookstores and got them to place the book. Bookstores were different then: small, individually owned, run by kindly gnomes with a tolerance for eccentricity. They must have thought that I was a fool or a lunatic, or — in the Toronto parlance ofthe day — "different", but this did not seem to bother them. As the book was small, it sold for 50 cents. I should have kept 249 of the things, as the price has now gone up considerably. The title of this tiny but peculiar effort was Double Persephone; the poems rhymed and scanned, and were about sex and death, with some rebirth tossed in: my optimism was showing early. As I recall, the word chthonic was in them, so it was pretty deep stuff. What do I think of them now? They weren't very good, but at least they were — oh, killing term — promising. I've been cheered up since by reading the juvenilia of other poets whose mature work I admire: Tennyson, for instance, has one that begins, "Airy, fairy Lilian". Best advice for young writers? This is a risky business. You're on a tightrope. Below is Niagara Falls. Courage. One step at a time. Don't look down. Margaret Atwood's latest novel is Oryx and Crake (Virago, £7.99; offer, £6.79)

My editor would be a fellow English literature student, the jacket would be designed by someone at the art college, and one of my tutors would act as proof-reader. I was on the road, but had no idea how long and strange the trip would be. Ian Rankin's latest book is Fleshmarket Close (Orion, £17.99; offer, £14.39)

would you take your own books with you? We laughed, and said no. My first book was lucky to come out at all, first because it was a collection of short stories. These are doomed in the trade, as all short story writers know, because publishers are constantly telling us so. Short stories "don't sell; readers don't buy them because readers don't like them". Actually, readers tend to love short stories. Everywhere I go, and everywhere I read to audiences, audiences tell me they love short stories. You'd never know this from, for example, The Big Read, because if you voted for a book of short stories on this scheme your vote was automatically discounted. No small reads allowed. It's harder to find short stories in bookshops. They go almost immediately on publication straight on to the shelves, whereas novels tend to lie around on tables and in display units for months, so there's hardly any browser purchase on stories. They get less review coverage. Publishers tend to pay much less for marketing them via book reps and sellers. Publishers would soon change their tune about short stories if there was, say, a major money prize, or a short story category on the Whitbread. I sent out my first collection, Free Love and Other Stories, to several publishers in 1994 and kept getting the same kind of letter back. We like these, but they're short stories. Can you write a novel? Eventually Virago took a chance and accepted them. I was ecstatic. I went to their offices in Camden and met my future editor, Ruth Petrie. The next day I heard she'd left and the company was going bankrupt. Oh, no! Then Virago got bought by a conglomerate. My book was sure to get lost in the scrum, I thought. But doughty Lennie Goodings brought it out, a small print run in a quite unusual shape, long and thin. Lennie kindly let me have the cover I wanted, a picture of Louise Brooks from the G. W. Pabst film Diary of a Lost Girl (1929). There were a few reviews. It won a prize. Virago was pleased. They asked: next time, can you write a novel? AH Smith's latest book is The Whole Story and Other Stories (Penguin, £7.99; offer, £6.79)
sumed that it must be my first book. No one had heard ofthe little Iron Press or the little Sleepless Nights. But both books shared a starting point in a room in an ancient Suffolk farm, and both were similarly important to me, in building that unpredictable pursuit called a literary career. David Almond's latest book is Kate, the Cat and Moon (illustrated by Stephen Lambert), Hodder Children's Books, £10.99; offer, £8.79
My first published book was a long time coming. I wrote a novel when I was 15 or 16. It was penned longhand on stolen school jotters, and concerned a teenager who, misunderstood in his small-town home, flees to the seedy glamour of London, where he ends up jumping into the Thames and drowning. My follow-up was a themed collection — poems, short stories and a novella — on the loose subject of room/space. The novella was an updating of Lord of the Flies to a comprehensive school, where a poster of Mick Jagger was having a demonic influence on the younger kids,. So far, so bad. When I reached university, I drifted from the novel to the poem. (I say "novel", but doubt that these early efforts would have stretched beyond 20 or 30 typed pages.) I was 22 when I started work on a comedy set in a Highland hotel. It was called Summer Rites and featured a one-legged, schizophrenic librarian, a famous American author kidnapped by the paramilitary wing of the Scottish National Party, and a young kid with paranormal powers. I sent this off to various publishers, none of which could see the genius of the piece. It probably didn't help that, although the thing was put together on a typewriter, I had yet to learn to put a space after each punctuation mark and two after a period. (It was single-spaced to boot.) Putting Summer Rites behind me, I started work on a long short story, which eventually became the opening section of The Flood. I was 23 and doing a doctoral thesis on the novels of Muriel Spark. But really I was spending more time on my own writing. Living in Edinburgh, I peered enviously across to Glasgow, where writers such as Alasdair Gray and James Kelman were igniting Scottish fiction. No more Miss Jean Brodies. The Flood was a fairly traditional narrative, a typical Bildungsroman in that it dealt with the town of my youth, none too well disguised. When the novel was finished, I took it in person to a publisher called Polygon. At that time, Polygon had just published Kelman's first collection of short stories, and was about to publish his first novel. Moreover, it was owned by the Edinburgh University Students' Publication Board. Soon, I began hearing rumours that the book would be accepted. The letter arrived at my bedsit, announcing that Polygon would be happy to print up 200 hardbacks and 800 paperbacks. They would pay me £200.
I've never sat down and re-read any of my own books. Why would I? I still remember them pretty much off by heart. I know what happens in them. I'd want to change things. I'd just get annoyed with myself. Maybe when I'm an old old lady in my nineties, if I live that long, I'll look at them again. But I doubt it; I think there'll always be something else, new or old, I'd rather read. Gertrude Stein on her death bed lamented the shortness of life and the too-many-books of it. Why would you ever want to read your own? When the first bound copy comes through the door from the publisher, that's it — finished. I was recently on a Desert Island books panel at the Edinburgh Festival with a couple of other writers; someone in the audience asked,

Title: New Novels
Full_text:
NEW NOVELS.
Among new novels are A. L. Aldanov's Trn DEVIL'S Bninn, translated from the Russian by A. E. Chamnot (Knopf, 7s. 6d. net), and Mr. William MoFee's Pnaramxs OF ADVERsITy (Heinemann, 7s. 6d. net).
"The Devil's Bridge" is the middle part of a historical trilogy dealing with European policies during the Napoleonic period. The earlier volumne, " The Ninth Thermidor," although it surveyed the European scene from a Russian viewpoint, was principally occupied with events in Fhrance, and this present volume is likewise chiefly concerned with historical occurrences outside Russia. Young Staal is in Petersburg at the beginiing, a witness of the g,ruesome death of Catherine and of the equaly gruesome accession of Paul. But lie soon goes. off to Venice, and arrives in time to see something of the Revolution of 1797, the spirit of which is ironically contrasted with the spirit of 1789. Returning to Petersburg, Staal leaves alnost imnmediately to take part in Suvarov's campaign against the 3French
in the Alps. *The account of the battle of Tovi is brilliantly done, one of the best things in the novel being the description of' Joubert's tactics. The whole thin is impressive in its easy handling of the crowded, intricate scene ; perhaps the historical alusions are a little too fine at times, but, on the -whole, the author bears his considerable learning with marked lightness.
A ship, a South American Republic, an insurrection, a railway to be exploited, a seaboard town with a pension kept by an elderly Englishwoman and a cafe kept by an intriguing native, a ramification of conflicting political and economic interests, a stolid young Scotsman with a certain unsatisfied hunger for romance, and a lovely, hot-blooded Southern girl who throws herself under the protection of his chivalry-these are the ingredients of Mr. William MeFee's " Pilgrims of Adversity." The reader, perhaps, can almost guess the use he maakes of them. We need not describe the condition of the Candleshoe's engines: they keep three engineers very busy, and these three engineers, as well as Captain Millerton and the twvo mates, are very diverse characters, too fully described. Author: J. S.
Title: New Novels
Full_text:
NEW NOVELS
STAYING IN PARIS
PARISIAN HOLIDAY. By VERA WATSON.
Cape. 7s. 6d.
0. HENRY ENCORE. Edited by MARY
SUNLOCKS HARRELL. Hodder and Stoughton. 7s. 6d.
A TIME TO CAST AWAY. By EDWARD S.
HYAMS. Methuen. 8s. 6d.
NOBODY ORDERED WOLVERS. By JEFFREY
DELL. Heinemann. 7s. 6d.
A minor but regrettable conscquence of the- war is that one cannot go to Paris -or rather, that it would not be the same. No doubt it is frivolous to complain, but those occasional long week-ends, if only once or twice a year, were good for selfesteem. At the cost of a few pounds one could feel oneself a citizen of the world, and it was pleasant to buy a shirt or a tie and speak modestly of shopping in Paris. As for the Parisians, encounters with porters, taxi-drivers, waiters, and the proprietor of a favourite small hotel made one an authority on the subject, and it is only in reading such a book as PARISIAN HOLIDAY that the bubble bursts. Of course we did not know the French-but Miss Vera Watson will make the introductions.
The English girl on holiday is not quite new to the Continent. Her home is -in Switzerland, so that she has taken at least the first step towards knowing that there are no such things as foreigners, but only men and women with different histories. *At the Duplessis', however, she enters a French family circle for the first time, and she finds it more amiable than alarming, more admirable than severe, and more raisonnable than reasonable-that is to say, Colonel and Mme. Duplessis and their children can always think of justifications for their absurdities. On the pretext of holding a family council they indulge their fondness for gossip, and a round of tea or port when Madame's sister has been routed, or Yvonne and her husband have fallen out, or tempers have been tried in discussing Marie Antoinette is one of their most characteristic and endearing pleasures. Miss Watson is neither earnest nor pretentious. Her picture is restricted to a single unremarkable family, which is to be liked as well as laughed at, and though Arlette's misdemeanours are not to be excused on the grounds of her being unhappily in love, there is a romantic precedent for them. At any rate, the plot suffices to show off the foibles, principles, and good qualities of some engaging people.
0. HENRY STORIES
We must turn to 0. Henry for the life of a city on the other side of the worldand not New York this time. A new volume of his work is now available, and in these early stories and, sketches, unearthed from the files of the Houston Post of 1896, the proper magic is already active. Civic pride seldom prevents a man-unless, indeed, he is a citizen of Paris-from fancying that life elsewhere is somehow more eventful and stimulating, with less of Monday about it and more of Saturday; and one of 0. Henry's remarkable gifts was the discovery, or the professed discovery, of gold in common places. One can imagine the satisfaction with which citizens of Houston, Texas, at.that time would read in their newspaper, and for a moment almost believe, that adventure
had been on their doorsteps: how a private detective had been bamboozled by a thief ; how a* tipsy gentleman had showered banknotes on the sick-bed of a newspaper boy; how a Houston dandy had turned friar in Italy; and how Colonel Warburton Pollock explained the peculiar luxuriance of M. Paderewsky's hair. When we have read such pieces as " The Pink Flask," which depends solely on the efforts of an abstainer to rid himself of somebody else's whisky bottle, and "The Mirage ,on the Frio," the inspiration of Mr. Saroyan and other modern writers is plain. The humour is kind and the kindness niever sentimental, and there is something 'not positively unpleasant about readinglAmerican literature that is still written in English.
CHANGING AN: ACCOUNTANT
English books written not wholly in English are also to be found, and we must admit with regret that A TaIE TO CAST AWAY has some lapses. This is the more curious when a. description of washerwomen scrubbing " tough fabrics " follows. hard on a quotation from Jane Austen, and the more regrettable because it makes for a continual small distraction from Mr. Edward S. Hyams's interesting matter. His theme has unusual possibilities. An accountant with a conventional mind is thrown into the company of people who might have come out of " Point Counterpoint," but come, in fact, from Balham. Attracted by a Frenchwoman more polite than her friends, he allows himself to listen, with some surprise, to conversations in which the cutting, the destructive, and the perverse are most valued and which have a quaint flavour of old-fashioned anarchy. Unfortunately, heiis bored, but the lady is a more effectual'influence. She takes him to a concert and gets him to admit that the music angered him. She teaches him to drive a car and see himself in a new light. She is responsible at last for his embezzlement, not because she is greedy, but because she is curious to see him assert himself. They then flee to France. At its most annoying the book is seldom dull, and the evident struggle between Mr. Hyams's active mind and his solemn, exaggerated expression is most promising.
But for real anarchy there is nothing like the film studios. When we weary of the films themselves we never lose interest in the old ritual necessary to make them. NOBODY ORDERED WOLVES is- the latest celebration of the extravagance, delay, and muddle with which studios every-where are always credited, and anyone who has .paid a visit to them knows that there is at any rate a little truth in the charges.- Mr. Jeffrey Dell's celebration is gay, inventive, and as fresh as the subject will allow. His foreign producer is more of a character than most of his kind in fiction, and the attempt to make use of a pack of wolves that no one remembers ordering provides some fascinating episodes. According to this comedy, the British studios are at least as fantastic as those in Hollywood, and the adventures of Phillip Hardcastle in search of the work for which he is being paid Â£2,000 a vear;
are exceedingly funny.
J. S.

Author: Null
Title: New Paths In Book Collecting
Full_text:
"NEW PATHS IN BOOK-
COLLECTING "
DETECTIVE FICTION AND
WAR BOOKS
The exhibition to be opened to-morrow in Messrs. J. and E. Bumpus's rooms in Oxford Street is more ambitious than most of a distinguished series of exhibitions and also of more popular appeal. Called " New Paths in Book-Collecting," it brings a rich man's hobby wijhin the reach of every man, and many of the " new paths," if new to collectors, are old favourites among readers.
Thus one section is devoted entirely to detective fiction. There are assembled all the historical landmarks in this field: Poe's tales in ' yellow-back " form, "The Moonstone "; a book of which over half a million copies were sold. Fergus Hume's " Mystery of a Hansom Cab "; the Sherlock Holmes volumes in their rare first editions; and the earliest detective book by each of such popular authors as Mr. Austin Freeman, Baroness Orczy, Mr. A. E. WV. klason, Mr. E. C. Bentley, Miss Dorothy Sayers, Father Ronald Knox, and Mr. and Mrs. G. D. H. Cole.
Another section covers first editions of War books. Here are not only novels by Mr. A. P. Herbert, Mr. R. H. Mottrain, and others, and poems by Robert Bridges and Mr. Laurence Binyon, but such autobiographies as Mr. Robert Graves's " Good-bye to All That " (a bibliographical rarity) and Mr. Siegtried Sassoon's two volumes of mernoirs. Moreover, proof copies are shown of the text of the peace treaties with Bulgaria and Austria; and the ephemeral War-time literature-broadsides and pamphletsnow very difficult to obtain, is represented.
To illustrate the scope of " authbT collections," which the true collector does not limit to his author's first editions, much interesting material has been assembled. In panicular, the sections devoted to Mr. Kipling and Colonel Lawrence deserve attention. Mr. Kipling's works were " pirated " more widely than any other author's in the eighteen-nineties and nineteenhundreds: and a large body of his works lent by the Kipling Society is interestingly supplemented by the private collection of Mr. W. A. Young. Colonel Lawrence's " Seven Pillars of Wisdom " is a rare book, seldom seen. Messrs. Bumpus are able to exhibit not only part of the manuscript and proofs of the verv expensive illustrated edition, but also a copy of a practically unknown edition of eight copies printed in double columns in a newspaper office in Oxford in 1920. There is also other valuable Lawrcnce material.
"YELLOW-BACKS"
Morc peculiarly for the bibliomaniac, but of interest to those who in their vouth bought a now obsolete type of railway tiction, is a chronological exhibit of " ycllow-backs." These are of value as an illustration of middle nineteenth-century publishing history, but they are also pleasantly reminisceni of a more picturcsque period than to-day. Here in their gaudy boardbindings are the Captain Marryats, the Charles Levers, the Bulwer Lyttons, Trollopcs, and Ouidas; even, in surprising contrast, the Hardys and the Nat Goulds. And in another section are other. more artistic and more durable series -books illustrated in the eighties and nineties by Hugh Thompson, the Brocks, Arthur Rackham, Walter Crane, Bernard Partridge, and Gordon Craig.
Finally m.y be mentioned what to the publisher and book-collector at least will seem the cxhibition's most important contribution{ to the historical study of book production-a very comprehensive survey of bookbinding styles, from the sheepskins and vellums of the seventeenth century, through paper-wrappers and paperboards, down to the gilded and printed cloths of the present age.
MODERN HEBREW LITERATURE
In connexion with the forthcoming " Hebrew Week " an exhibition of modern Hebrew books will be held at the Foyle Art Gallery from November 26 to December 3. The exhibition is to portray the use of Hebrew as a living language from the eighteenth century to the prescnt day, and will include printed books, manuscripts. plhotographs, and journals. The
Hebrew Week " Committee would be grateful if those who possess suitable material, which is not usually accessible, were to lend it to the exhibition. Persons willing to lend such material are asked to send a description of it to Mr. N. S. Doniach, care of Messrs. Foyles, 119-125, Charing Cross Road, W.C.2. Full responsibility will be taken for all material exhibited.

Author: Null
Title: New Novels
Full_text:
NEW NOVELS
Among new novels are SEVEN BASKETFllLS, by Theodora Benson and Betty Askwith (Gollancz, '7s. 6d. net) ; TIIE MStANOR HOUSF., by lXetta Syrett (Bles, 7s. 6d. net) ; and A XVmlrn'S P.AssioN, by Doris Langley Moore (Heinemann, 7s. 6d. net).
Mliss Theodora Benson and Aliss Betty Askwvith carry on their spirited partnership and have produced another young and cheerful novel which has a pleasant note of sincerity. It is all very slight, but very well told; the tale of Philip Hailing who loved and was loved, but unluckily not as lie desired. Lovely Joyce did not want him permanently in her life, where ho wished to remain, and steadfast Georgina hoped for nothing more than to pick up the remains of his squandered affection and make what she could of it. The girls are charming and real, and -the young man is real and charming to them, which is as it should be. The atmosphere of carefree youth and discovery is attractive: "Does it not seem odd when one has macle a great mental stride that one's intimlates do not automatically assimilate the fact vithout having to have it explained ? They do in truth grasp at once the things one doesn't want them to. HIas one ever had to explain that one is stupidly attracted by that dreadful little dago or that literary oddity ? Everyone feels it as a matter of course in the air. And so it is always irritating and stirprising if, for instance,. one has just discovered Bach and a friend then speaks as if his music bored one still."
"The Manor House " is a well-handl6d tale of no special originality, but pleasant because it has a feeling of English country and because it utters a heartfelt protest against the passing of property and all feudal feeling. Iiss Syrett deals lavishly in romance, but she is competent and interesting, and her Ann, the gardener's daughter who becomes a land-worker and in time the capable mistress of the estate on which she was born, is a living and lovable creature.
"A Winter's Passion" is the longdrawn-out but well-told tale of a young wife's deliberate infatuation for a young .ian wvho ,was almost too beautiful to be true, but who did in time yield to her plotted blandislunents. A few hours ^nded the affair, and.Mrs. Edward Shearbridge, of Mloorcross, Yorkshire, who relates the story of her passion with candour and obvious enjoyment, got a lesson that she did not anticipate which sent her in full confession back to her husband's arms. The touch of tragedy at the end is a surprise to the .reader as well, wrho cannot regret that Caroline's complacency should be shocked. This is a clever book, entirely on the material plane.

Lovely Joyce did not want him permanently in her life, where ho wished to remain, and steadfast Georgina hoped for nothing more than to pick up the remains of his squandered affection and make what she could of it. The girls are charming and real, and the young man is real and charming to them, which is as it should be. The atmosphere of carefree youth and discovery is attractive: "Does it not seem odd when one has macle a great mental stride that one's intimlates do not automatically assimilate the fact vithout having to have it explained ? They do in truth grasp at once the things one doesn't want them to. HIas one ever had to explain that one is stupidly attracted by that dreadful little dago or that literary oddity ? Everyone feels it as a matter of course in the air. And so it is always irritating and stirprising if, for instance,. one has just discovered Bach and a friend then speaks as if his music bored one still." "The Manor House " is a well handl6d tale of no special originality, but pleasant because it has a feeling of English country and because it utters a heartfelt protest against the passing of property and all feudal feeling. Iiss Syrett deals lavishly in romance, but she is competent and interesting, and her Ann, the gardener's daughter who becomes a land worker and in time the capable mistress of the estate on which she was born, is a living and lovable creature. "A Winter's Passion" is the longdrawn out but well told tale of a young wife's deliberate infatuation for a young .ian wvho ,was almost too beautiful to be true, but who did in time yield to her plotted blandislunents. A few hours nded the affair, and.Mrs. Edward Shearbridge, of Mloorcross, Yorkshire, who relates the story of her passion with candour and obvious enjoyment, got a lesson that she did not anticipate which sent her in full confession back to her husband's arms. The touch of tragedy at the end is a surprise to the .reader as well, wrho cannot regret that Caroline's complacency should be shocked. This is a clever book, entirely on the material plane.

Title: New Novels
Full_text:
NEW NOVELS
_-- - --M
MR. CAPEK'S ORDINARY
MAN
AN ORDINARY LIFE. BY KAREL CAPEK.
Translated by M. and R. WEATHERALL. Allen and Unwin. 7s. 6d.
With this volume Karel Capek has completed what is fairly described as an ideological trilogy, of which the earlier two volumes were Hordubal "-and" Meteor." In these he was concerned with the legend of the individual personality as it was created by other people; in this latest story it is the legend as created by oneself which provides the theme. An old man of 70. formerly a country station-master and now living in retirement in Prague, is possessed by the feeling of death and sits down to write his autobiography. The first half of the book, a grave and delicate evocation of scenes from the past, is beautifully done, the glimpses of childhood in particular being rendered with uncommon sensitiveness. The earliest indication that there is a distinction between telling the truth about oneself and wanting to tell the truth about oneself comes with the account of a brief period of study at the university at Prague. The folly, the verses, the not very creditable escapades appear, but the narrator is plainly evasive, though unconsciously so.
He describes his first job as a railway clerk, his life at a station somewhere in the mountains, his courtship and marriage, his sober and well-ordered existence as station-master, his participation in the Czech nationalist movement after the outbreak of war. It is the uneventful record of the most ordinary of men, though Mr. Capek sees to it that there is art enough in the telling. And then comes a sudden break in the story: by the narrator's side appears his familiar, an anxious and sceptical spirit. Is there such a thing as an ordinary life ? Where in the record is there mention of the undisciplined, romantic feeling which the prudent habit of years has not stifled ? Or of the " man with elbows," who used love and sentiment to push his way in the world ? Or of the hypochondriacal emotion perpetually warring with physical appetite ? Or of the strange, tormenting streak of depravity ? The somewhat psycho-analytical manner of the later half impairs the story-teller's art, but is evidence of the cunning of Mr. Capek's imaginative conception.
THE SOUND WAGON. By T. S. STRIBLING.
Gollancz. 8s. 6d.
This novel is a sardonic indictment of politics in the United States, and those 1 who have the patience to read it and dis-
entangle from the long conversations the dirtier and dirtier actions in which the amiable hero is forced to acquiesce in his rise from reform candidate to Senator will be forced to reflect with amazement on the state of affairs that it purports to reveal.
All the leading characters, with the exception of Henry Caridius himself and the inventor, Essary, are completely cynical: in fact, the dry comments of the lawyer Myerberg are, in their irony, among the few diverting features of this Balzacian indictment. Caridius, a likeable, " biddable," and amorous man, finding himself unsuccessful as a lawyer, stands for Congress as an independent reformer. He is elected because his sitting opponent has suddenly died, and a little double-voting is easily organized by the machine, which he thereby enters. The most powerful force in the machine is Littenham, president of a bank and a munitions organization, owner of several newspapers and innumerable political consciences. Another very powerful force is Joe Canarelli, the racketeer, of Megalopolis. Both, in different ways, are ruthless criminals, who normally work together. But Canarelli is crossed by Littenham and vows vengeance. Caridius becomes a pawn in the game, and his secretary, Littenham's daughter, becomes a victim. The details are complicated, the facts horrible, and the moral seems to be that, as Myerberg remarks, the only hope for better government in the United States is that racketeering should get a firm hold of the Federal courts and police. " When that time comes, racketeering will be just as respectable as banking is to-day . . . and then we will undoubtedly enjoy a new and refreshing recrudescence of 'honour' in American life." For an Englishman this novel is rather difficult reading, but as a pamphlet it is remarkable.
MEN AND BRETHREN. BY JAMES GOULD
COZZENS. Longmans. 7s. 6d.
Mr. Cozzens's new novel is one perhaps to be primarily commended to the perceptive reader, for whom characterization is more than story. There is indeed plenty of incident, but having continuity only in the growing light thrown upon the central figure of the Reverend Ernest Cudlipp, vicar of St. Ambrose in New York, a middle-aged priest whose certainty of faith is only equalled by the assurance with which he scampers about, feet solid on earth, handling the problemsmostly other people's-which press in upon him from every side. For some reason clergymen at once credible and likeable are in fiction generally men filled with doubt concerning their own profession; Mr. Cozzens, whatever his own personal point of view, performs something of a feat in presenting one who is both despite his steadfastness. Many are the difficulties he is forced to face in the space of a single day and night (or more exactly evening and next day), but from first to last he succeeds in moving to and fro between them all, a complete human being.
MARCHING MINSTREL. BY VIOLET CAMP-
BELL. Murray. 7s. 6d.
Perroguet was a minstrel, half French, half Spanish, who roamed for a living with flute and guitar, sang songs and told stories. He was caught up in the retreat to Coruhia of Sir John Moore's Army and, when it had embarked for home, found himself with a baby girl upon his hands, her mother having followed the army to the last and died of exposure. This book is an account of his career, of that of his foundling and, finally, of her son's. It is in the romantic tradition and at times not without that tradition's besetting garishness. Yet when one compares it with the many romances in similar vein one realizes how greatly Mrs. Campbell's gifts of imagination and characterization excel those of the majority of her rivals. The tale is largely concerned with life in travelling circuses, in which all the three principal characters are engaged, and this is described with skill, humour, and at times grimness. A few of the great make a momentary appearance: Murat entering Madrid, Moore marching to his death, Byron in a postchaise, and long afterwards Garibaldi marching out of Rome after its surrender to the French. They are, however, in the background, as they would be to circus folk.

Title: Books For Backward Readers
Full_text:
BOOKS FOR BACKWARD
READERS
Two exhibitions of books for backward readers opened at the London headquarters of the National Book League yesterday.
Arranged by Mr. S. S. Segal, chairman of the Guild of Teachers of Backward Children, the exhibitions are subsidized bv the Nuffield Foundation. The leaguLe intend to h:re them to education authorities and other interested bodies. Teachers who see them will be asked to complcte a questicnnaire, to give their opinion of books en show and to add any others they think useful.
Mr. Scgal considers that ovcr the past five years publishers have become more and more interested in the market for reading books. not cnly fcr normal and backward children but children learning Engiish abroad. e;pezially in the developing countries. For backward children, however. the publisher may have to specialize.
Because publishers are only gradually waking up to the potential markct in backward readers, Mr. Segal has put many books not specifically written for them into the exhibitions. The Times Book of Zoo Animals and others which are well printed and illustrated are included, as they lure the reluctant to read. Even so the:> is a shortage of material for girls and fer all backward ohildren between 11 and lo.
Mr. Scgal looks forward to a much greater expenditure by local education authorities on books for the backward (all book purchases are no more than 1 per cent of their total budget at present. he says): to more courses training tcachers for thcm; and. before long he hopes, to a university chair in special education.

Even so the: is a shortage of material for girls and fer all backward ohildren between 11 and lo. Mr. Scgal looks forward to a much greater expenditure by local education authorities on books for the backward (all book purchases are no more than 1 per cent of their total budget at present. he says): to more courses training tcachers for thcm; and. before long he hopes, to a university chair in special education.

Author: J. S.
Title: New Novels
Full_text:
NEW NOVELS FREE-LANCE JOURNALIST
BE A GENT, LItTLE WOMAN, BE A GENT.
By EILEEN WINNCROFT.. John Lane. 7s. 6d.
AvrER, THE DEATH OF DON JUAN. By
SYLVIA TOWNSEND WARNER. Chatto and Windus. 7s. 6d.
ENTANGLEMENT. By GEORGE BUCHANAN.
Constable. 8s. 6d.
FLYING ,COLOURS. By C. S. FORESTER.
Michael Joseph. 7s. 6d.
BE A GENT, LITTLE W'OMAN, BE A GENT -the extraordinary title has the effect intended. Call it long, slangy, nonsensical, comically suggestive; the fact remains that curiosity is aroused. What manner of woman is thus exhorted to be-well, not even a gentleman at full length ? And is one to take it that " being a gent " is merely a racier expression for the Tennysonian virtues-? Unlike the headlines in the newspapers, the title is discreet. It gives nothing away. Read the book we must, if curiosity is to be satisfied. Having caught the reader's eye, which is half an author's battle, Miss Eileen Winncroft proceeds to hold it more or less fixedly for the course of the book.
On the whole, it is an original, unconventional, unpretentious little thing, the account of two or three intelligent and. temperamental young people who like to make their own mistakes. There are-times when the stream of chatter that bears along the story grows sluggish and dwindles to a kind of " gossipese, buit these are infrequent. Generally Forest (the Little Wonian of the title) and Sean. her beautiful, idle husband. are carried wherever her work as a free-lance journalist and.his evasions take them, and the rapid flow of the narrative does indeed suggest the speed with which life can take a man nowhere. In spite of occasional sentimental nonsense, the author talks a good deal of sense lightly and humorously on ,the subject of personal relationships, with which her characters are almost exclusively occupied; and if anyone doubts the charm and futility of Sean he has only to look about -him at his own acquaintances to find some other with charm and no intention of doing any work. The type is not uncommon. But we have not yet looked at this mysterious state known as "being a gent." The implication is, it appears, that a " gent " will not take advantage of her sex to be a bully and will make every effort to behave as a rational and generous human being.
A SEQUEL TO MOZART
The professional reader must always be fascinated by his armchair travels. He will spend the morning and afternoon with Miss Winncroft in or about Fleet Street, and immediately after dinner Miss Sylvia Warner whisks him off to Spain and the past. AFTER THE DEATH OF DON JUAN begins, as the advertisement says, where Don Giovanni leaves off. The Commander has appeared from the dead, the floor has opened, or so. Leporello says, and Don Juan has made a sudden sulphurous departure. Nothing will now content the Commander's-daughter but to inform Don Juan's father in person; and having married Ottavio and engaged Leporello as his valet, on the flimsy pretext that Leporello was the last person to see the Commander, she sets out for the countrv. There evervone is seriously concerned with this accident to Don Juan. His father is grateful that there will be no more demands for money but laments the lack of an heir, and the peasants long to credit the news, for if the son is dead the father may have money to spare to irrigate their lands. That is the rough outline of the position, and in the book Miss Warner fills this in with a loose mosaic pattern of lesser issues. Revolt, spasmodic liberalism, avarice. fear, stupidity, and, when Don Juan himself makes an appearance, the most ruthless selfishness are pieces in it, and Miss Warner makes the nicest compromise between passion and dry humour in arranging them.
A STUDY OF LOVE
And with ENTANGLENIENT the magic armchair is never still. In his new novel Mr. George Buchanan takes one about London with a group of people whose associations with one another are sufiicient to provide a loose and elastic form. The period is the last 18 months, and the people are somethina like a miniature of society. Though the preoccupation is superficially with politics, the book may be taken as fundamentally a study of love, and of love extended to humanity at large. To illustrate this, the people are of all classes and ages, and each appears at a different stage in the slow attempt of man to put off self. Some, like Lady Zia, seem beyond hope; for others, like her daughter, who is not yet set into the fashionable mould, there is still hope; and some, like Lady Zia's husband, who started in youth with liberal ideals, have gradually lost sight of these in the pursuit of culture or material advancement. Much of the material, it is true, is known to us already, but Mr. Buchanan is very good at going a shade deeper beneath the surface and fishing up an unexpected thought. There are parts, too, where, though one is generally persuaded by his arguments, one is not convinced of the truth of a reading; and yet, in the superb description of the multifarious activities of London at any single moment, which serves for an epitome of the society examined in detail, he is not to be assailed.
How reassuring it is to pass to the clear anxieties of Captain Hornblower, R.N.. in FLYING COLOURS, the latest account of his adventures ! He is imprisoned, at the point where we left him in "A Ship of the Line," in Napoleonic Spain, and Mr. Forester's new novel describes the marvellous hardships and adventures of Hornblower, Lieutenant Bush, whose foot was shot away in the last battle, and Coxswain
Brown on their way to Paris and, after months of hiding, down to the sea again. The new novel differs from its predecessors in being less credible, but Mr. Forester's power to make the details realistic remains. We may not believe that three men, one of them recently maimed, could make their way in safety, on a winter night, down a strange river in full flood, but we are given every encouragement to do so. We may doubt the infinitesimal chance that brought them, in a hostile country, to the one house that would shelter and assist them to escape at a more favourable time; but we must admit that, once there, they behave very naturally, and that, when they have set out once more, their recapture of the prize cutter and the battle they fight in the bay have all the old cxcitement.
J. S.

Author: Macintyre, Ben
Title: 'We are a nationa of age-defying, tea-bag-card-making crochet fans'
Full_text:
ndpapers
Ben Macintyre TWe are a nation of age-defying, tea-bag-card-making crochet fans'
THE BOOKS THAT WE BORROW SAY more about our literary tastes than the books that we own. If your bookshelves are anything like mine, they contain several hundred acres of the printed word that will never be read, at least not by me. There are Christmas gifts that we never wanted but cannot throw away, books we feel that we ought to read but cannot face and the obligatory copy of Stephen Hawking's A Brief History of Time, that will never be opened because life is several aeons too short. But library books are different. People borrow the library books that they actually want, and then actually read them. Unlike the bestseller lists, they are not an index of fashion, of reviews and book clubs, or of the effects of marketing and advertising. Library books are the works of literature that we want to read but not necessarily to own and keep. The Public Lending Rights figures for the most-borrowed books, published this week, offer a strange and revealing snapshot of modern Britain. To judge from the statistics, our love affair with romantic fiction has ended; instead, we have taken up with television chefs, crochet-hooks, French people and cricketers. For 17 years Dame Catherine Cookson, queen of the pot-boiler romance, has reigned
* m
supreme in Britain's public libraries. In 1994, she occupied numbers one to nine in the top ten most borrowed books list, with Barbara Taylor Bradford sneaking into the No 10 spot. Today, Dame Catherine does not figure in the top ten. For the third year running, the most borrowed writer in Britain is the children's author Jacqueline Wilson. J. K. Rowling, by comparison, limps in at No 74. Of the 20 most-borrowed children's titles, 16 are by the staggeringly prolific Ms Wilson. Casting an eye down the most-borrowed titles list, it becomes clear that there is a special category of book that people like to borrow in huge numbers, but do not wish to possess, just in case the neighbours come round. Trinny and Susannah, Kim and Aggie, Paul McKenna and Gillian McKeith all do well in this category. To borrow and read these books is one thing, but to have them in your bookshelves practically screams: I am a badly-dressed, unhygienic, slightly bonkers person worried about my bodily functions. The evergreen Official Theory Test for Car Drivers by the Driving Standards Agency comes in at No 19, one below Dave Pelzer's The Lost Boy. This seems only right, since both are written in the same style: repetitive, glutinous and heart-wrenchingly sad. Cookery provides another window of revelation. In the country as a whole, we prefer Jamie Oliver's recipes, but this disguises wide regional culinary-literary variations. Londoners are gorging on Nigella Lawson, but the Welsh prefer Hugh Fearnley-Whittingstall. Welsh library habits deserve a study of their own. In dogs, for example, the Welsh look far afield, displaying a particular preference for Yorkshire terriers, despite the national affinity for labradors. Welsh travel reading, however, seems less adventurous. While other parts of the country read about France and Spain, and Londoners dream of Scotland, the favourite Welsh travel book is The Rough Guide to Wales. Books about moving abroad are being borrowed in record numbers, but luckily we don't all want to go to the same place. The occupants of the Orkney Islands read about moving to Tuscany; in Devon they imagine buying somewhere in France; in Northumberland they think about heading for the Australian
Outback. Most library users imagine moving to somewhere warmer, drier and more interesting, but not in Fife, where they still dream of relocating to Canada. Mind you, each region has foibles. By far the most popular pet books nationwide are about tortoises; except in Scotland where, apparently, people much prefer to read about snakes. As for hobbies, while Londoners love to crochet, in the North of England borrowers can't get enough of "Tea Bag Folded Greetings Cards", a pastime I have never even heard of before. The library lists also offer a rough guide to national hypochondria. Overall, the most-borrowed health book is Defying Age: How to Think, Act and Stay Young. It may come as no surprise to discover that the most popular medical book in the libraries of Northern Ireland is Stress and Nervous Disorders; in Wales readers mug up on The Vitamins and Minerals Handbook, while Scottish readers like to relax with a well-thumbed library copy of How to Lower High Blood Pressure, preferably while smoking a fag and eating a deep-fried Mars bar. The top film, television and music biography last year was Being Jordan by Katie Price, whereas the top historical biography was Claire Tomalin's superb Samuel Pepys: The Unequalled Self. This may be a profoundly depressing statement about the contrast between great lives of the past and great lives ofthe present; on the other hand, I have a suspicion that Pepys and Jordan would have got on rather well. What we read also reflects what, and how, we like to kill. Our own Jane Shilling's The Fox in the Cupboard is the most popular British book in the hunting, shooting and fishing category, but in Scotland they prefer The Pigeon Shooter by John Batley, and in Wales David Brian Plummer's Ferrets. When the aliens finally land in Britain, they will no doubt head to the local library to mug up on exactly what sort of planet they have come to. There the real Britain will be revealed: a nation of age-defying, fox-hunting, tea-bag card-making, food-loving crochet fanatics most of whom, frankly, would rather be in Tuscany; or, if Welsh, in Wales. www.plr.uk.com

Author: Null
Title: New Novels
Full_text:
NEW NOVELS
- - ----b
THE REFLORESCENCE OF
PHILIP TRENT
TRENT'S OWN CASE. By E. C. BENTLEY
and H. WARNER ALLEN. Constable. 7s. 6d.
Midway between Sherlock Ho]mes and Peter Wimsey stands only one considerable figure-Philip Trent. Unlike theirs, his laurels bloomed early and faded soon. The Railway Murder, the Ilkley Mystery, the Abinger Case-these were never more than names ; and only diligent research in the Colindale depository of periodicals will reveal the uses to which, in his brief flower, he could put such different objects as a hairpin and a cockatoo. In 1913 he failed miserably to solve the murder of Sigsbee Manderson -so miserably that this became known the world over as " Trent's Last Case." Yet we think he would not have grudged the well-deserved success that his ill wind blew to Mr. E. C. Bentley.
Twenty-three vears have not changed Trent much; he still misquotes as freely as ever: more aptly than manv of his imitators. Nor had they weakened his resolution to lay off sleuthing but that almost all the persons involved in the murder of James Randolph were friends-or enemies -of his: this new case is thus peculiarly his " own." Most important of all, in 23 years his hand has regained its fabled cunning-metaphorically, that is, and in spite of leaving its fingerprints in suspicious places. The weakness of the present story, particularly in contrast with its brilliant predecessor, is that its complications arise not from the intellectual essentials-from the many possible interpretations of a few early-stated facts-but from the large variety of characters and the space allowed to the exploration of blind alleys. Trent's visits to Dieppe and to a City wine merchant, however, though they might have been curtailed to the advantage of the story, clearly provided the authors with amusement, and he will be a churlish reader who does not share it. (Observe a link between Mr. Warner Allen, author of "Mr. Clerihew, Wine Merchant," and Mr. E. Clerihew Bentley, the poetical innovators. The amusement has a heavy weight to balance-conventionalities like the Missing Will and the Missing Heir, the Sanctimonious Blackmailer, the Obscure Demoralizing Drug; for this reason no less than because the crowd is now denser " Trent's Own Case " does not stand out as high above the crowd as " Trent's Last Case " once did. But it is in the very first rank.
THE SEA'S A THIEF. By RONALD M.
LOCKLEY. Longmans. 7s. 6d.
Some novels leave with the reader nothing but a thrill, some leave also a picture of other people's lives. Three times in four these lives are urban or leisured or both. So a vivid story in which all the people are South Pembrokeshire fishermen and their womenfolk is welcome. The village of St. Martins appears to be close to Milford Haven, and the lobster fishers go as far afield as the " village city" of St. Davids northward (collisions with the Welsh result), or nearly to Tenby southward. And in one chapter Antoine and his friend Smy joined a trawler and fished off Donegal, enduring salt-water boils and other discomforts, and Smy was nearly killed when the bridle of the trawl came adrift. South Pembroke lobsters and crabs do not bring much profit, unless to the middleman. His account, reproduced in full, shows 26s. as a week's reward for two men and a boy and girl. And the women gathering laver at 4s. a cwt. do not add much.
Yet Antoine loved the sea. Six times in the book he exclaimed: " How wonderful the sea is ! " After Smy was drowned. and their hard-earned boat lost, he " finished with the sea " and turned quarryman. But at the end of the book both he and the also disappointed Big Tom were planning to fit another boat with an engine. There are some very finely written scenes, notably the rescue of 19 men, three women, and four children from a wreck on Black Stone, in the teeth of gale, tide, and " the great wind-manes that writhed on the belly of each mountainous sea." The heroic rescuers afterwards looted tools and gramophones from the wreck, but that will probably distress only unusually legal minds.
To SEE OURSELVES. By GuY C. POLLOCK
and ANNE ARMSTRONG. Hutchinson. 7s. 6d.
Taking with him his son Colin, aged six, Robert, seventeenth Baron Riddleton, made off to Canada without a word to anyone except the agent of his encumbered estate of Matching. Seventeen years later, when his wife and her two daughters were on the point of being dismissed to penury from Matching by the heir to the title who claimed that Robert was dead, there turned up a competent young colonial with all the papers required to prove that he was Colin and eighteenth Baron. As he was just the man Matching needed and had the money to restore it everything would have been splendid if he and Robert's daughter Susan had not fallen in love with one another. He observes the decencies by seeking safety in Canada; and the reader-always less ready than Courts to presume deaths-will hear without much surprise that he rejoined the now prosperous Robert and with no surprise that he was not Robert's son.
In this skeleton form the story may repel the fastidious. But the authors make the dry bones live in the hunting people of Matching and the prairie people of Robert's prosperous ranch. They even make us accept Robert. Who has the right to be odd, if not a seventeenth Baron ? Robert carries off his oddness with an air, and that though he ran away from Matching because he was frightened. It was family history that Matching was at feud with the men who owned it. and with that notion in his mind he had some ground for fearing that the house had been at its tricks with little Colin.
Cleaned_text: NEW NOVELS THE REFLORESCENCE OF PHILIP TRENT TRENT'S OWN CASE. By E. C. BENTLEY and H. WARNER ALLEN. Constable. 7s. 6d. Midway between Sherlock Ho mes and Peter Wimsey stands only one considerable figure Philip Trent. Unlike theirs, his laurels bloomed early and faded soon. The Railway Murder, the Ilkley Mystery, the Abinger Case these were never more than names ; and only diligent research in the Colindale depository of periodicals will reveal the uses to which, in his brief flower, he could put such different objects as a hairpin and a cockatoo. In 1913 he failed miserably to solve the murder of Sigsbee Manderson so miserably that this became known the world over as " Trent's Last Case." Yet we think he would not have grudged the well deserved success that his ill wind blew to Mr. E. C. Bentley. Twenty three vears have not changed Trent much; he still misquotes as freely as ever: more aptly than manv of his imitators. Nor had they weakened his resolution to lay off sleuthing but that almost all the persons involved in the murder of James Randolph were friends or enemies of his: this new case is thus peculiarly his " own." Most important of all, in 23 years his hand has regained its fabled cunning metaphorically, that is, and in spite of leaving its fingerprints in suspicious places. The weakness of the present story, particularly in contrast with its brilliant predecessor, is that its complications arise not from the intellectual essentials from the many possible interpretations of a few early stated facts but from the large variety of characters and the space allowed to the exploration of blind alleys. Trent's visits to Dieppe and to a City wine merchant, however, though they might have been curtailed to the advantage of the story, clearly provided the authors with amusement, and he will be a churlish reader who does not share it. (Observe a link between Mr. Warner Allen, author of "Mr. Clerihew, Wine Merchant," and Mr. E. Clerihew Bentley, the poetical innovators. The amusement has a heavy weight to balance conventionalities like the Missing Will and the Missing Heir, the Sanctimonious Blackmailer, the Obscure Demoralizing Drug; for this reason no less than because the crowd is now denser " Trent's Own Case " does not stand out as high above the crowd as " Trent's Last Case " once did. But it is in the very first rank. THE SEA'S A THIEF. By RONALD M. LOCKLEY. Longmans. 7s. 6d. Some novels leave with the reader nothing but a thrill, some leave also a picture of other people's lives. Three times in four these lives are urban or leisured or both. So a vivid story in which all the people are South Pembrokeshire fishermen and their womenfolk is welcome. The village of St. Martins appears to be close to Milford Haven, and the lobster fishers go as far afield as the " village city" of St. Davids northward (collisions with the Welsh result), or nearly to Tenby southward. And in one chapter Antoine and his friend Smy joined a trawler and fished off Donegal, enduring salt water boils and other discomforts, and Smy was nearly killed when the bridle of the trawl came adrift. South Pembroke lobsters and crabs do not bring much profit, unless to the middleman. His account, reproduced in full, shows 26s. as a week's reward for two men and a boy and girl. And the women gathering laver at 4s. a cwt. do not add much. Yet Antoine loved the sea. Six times in the book he exclaimed: " How wonderful the sea is ! " After Smy was drowned. and their hard earned boat lost, he " finished with the sea " and turned quarryman. But at the end of the book both he and the also disappointed Big Tom were planning to fit another boat with an engine. There are some very finely written scenes, notably the rescue of 19 men, three women, and four children from a wreck on Black Stone, in the teeth of gale, tide, and " the great wind manes that writhed on the belly of each mountainous sea." The heroic rescuers afterwards looted tools and gramophones from the wreck, but that will probably distress only unusually legal minds. To SEE OURSELVES. By GuY C. POLLOCK and ANNE ARMSTRONG. Hutchinson. 7s. 6d. Taking with him his son Colin, aged six, Robert, seventeenth Baron Riddleton, made off to Canada without a word to anyone except the agent of his encumbered estate of Matching. Seventeen years later, when his wife and her two daughters were on the point of being dismissed to penury from Matching by the heir to the title who claimed that Robert was dead, there turned up a competent young colonial with all the papers required to prove that he was Colin and eighteenth Baron. As he was just the man Matching needed and had the money to restore it everything would have been splendid if he and Robert's daughter Susan had not fallen in love with one another. He observes the decencies by seeking safety in Canada; and the reader always less ready than Courts to presume deaths will hear without much surprise that he rejoined the now prosperous Robert and with no surprise that he was not Robert's son. In this skeleton form the story may repel the fastidious. But the authors make the dry bones live in the hunting people of Matching and the prairie people of Robert's prosperous ranch. They even make us accept Robert. Who has the right to be odd, if not a seventeenth Baron ? Robert carries off his oddness with an air, and that though he ran away from Matching because he was frightened. It was family history that Matching was at feud with the men who owned it. and with that notion in his mind he had some ground for fearing that the house had been at its tricks with little Colin.

Author: J. S.
Title: New Novels
Full_text:
NEW NOVELS
THE GANGSTER CHILD
The criminal is naturally a conspicuous figure among law-abiding citizens, and on this truism Mr. Joyce Cary bases the tragedy of his erring boy in CHARLEY IS MY DARLING (Michael Joseph, 9s.). Charley must be conspicuous, not only as a London boy evacuated to the country, Charley must be admired; and for a time his lively fancy alone contents his audience. But children, like nations, sooner or later demand actions instead of words, and poor Charley has to substantiate his easy promises of entertainment and excitement. He steals a car to take the " gang " to the cinema and snatches a bag for ticket money; and it is not long before the need to keep up his reputation drives him to still worse follies. One cannot commend too highly this patient and penetrating analysis of children's minds, which convinces us of the probability of the most extravagant events and will not tolerate false sentiment.
Miss Aldyth Williams's PASTORAL SYMPHONY (Gollancz, 7s. 6d.) also discovers fresh interest in the countryside. Like " Rue with a Difference," this, too, mainly revolves about the Church, and there is a serious young rector who must learn to lead his parishioners to God at their own pace. But besides the sound of hymns, the gossip in the inn and in cottages, and the babel of a village bazaar there is a graver strain. A youth is encouraged by a vain, silly, and rather pathetic young girl and takes his own way out, and suddenly the village trivialities are silenced by the tragic. Mr. Jean Giono's latest novel, on the other hand, does not quite maintain the standard his other work has set. HARVEST (Heinemann, Ss. 6d.) describes the rebirth of a French mountain village when all the cottages are in ruins and only one man is left. It deals with his loneliness and his love simply and affectingly, it has great sensibility so far as Nature is concerned, and it knows how to profit by the joy most of us feel when something useful is made of what was derelict. But it has also a weakness from which Mr. Giono's "The Song of the World" was free: it is apt to seize on just those aspects of primitive living |that the English can seldom take seriouslv.
J. S.

Author: Null
Title: New Novels
Full_text:
NEW NOVELS
MISS G. B. STERN'S SEQUEL
SHINING AND FREE. By G. B. STERN.
(Heinemann. 7s. 6d.)
In her latest novel Miss G. B. Stern picks up the threads of Rakonitz history in the persons of the Matriarch, Truda, her daughter, and Iris and Maxine, her granddaughters. Neil Wyatt, her greatnephew, also unwillingly joins the Matriarch's glorious " spree " in Brighton, whither she has gone, the day before her eighty-eighth birthday, to collect the legacy of a commode: *The adventures of this day, on which the long-suffering Truda has told ~her to leave the house for ever, occupy the entire book. But no resume can give an adequate idea of the book's richness;of humanity and humour, its sudden flights into pity and pathos, and its rnellowness. It is a relief that *Miss Stern does not kill off the Matriarch at the end of the book, as it almost seemed she might. We want to read what happened on her ninetieth and hundredth birthdays. DANsNATION OF MR. ZINKLER. By GRAHAM
SuTroN. (Jonathan Cape. 7s. 6d.)
Pilate K. Zinkler was " a poor halfbaked sentimentalist,like therestof them: like' the cheap Woolworth Galahads they're always grinding out on their films -his films." So Kit Grenfell thought. Zinkler thought of Kit that, " He'd got a sorta childishness, like he'd missed part of his growth: like a kid . . . spoilt but nice." But what mattered most to both of them was what Jo Carbery thought of either. She thought of Kit that he "specialized in companionship: which means the use of people when you feel in the mood; and when you don't they're just shelved. Most women aren't satisfied with that. So Kit . . . hated women, I think." They learnt these truths, or halftruths, in Hades.
How they got to Hell, and what they found there, and how they tried to climb out makes a very exciting story. The reader can choose whether to give himself to the thrills, or to think out the philosophy, or to admire the ingenuity of the infernal arrangements. He can hardly fail to be amused, even if only at Mr. Zinkler's language. He can hardly fail to be puzzled. He may think Kit's final punishment unduly severe, though perhaps not more severe than life. And he may even wonder whether three or four hundred years of companionship even with Mr. Zinkler may make one tire of an " ideal sex-mate." But even when Mr. Sutton is most serious he can be funny' and there remains a suspicion that, at his funniest, he is inwardly serious.

Author: Baddiel, David
Title: 'What am I doing owning a copy of Make Your Own Fishing Tackle?'
Full_text:
ook,
David Baddiel fWhat am I doing owning a copy of Kake Your Own Fishing Tackle?1
WHAT DO ADOLF HITLER, MARY Whitehouse, Jimmy Greaves and Dick Emery have in common? Probably quite a lot if you do enough research, but the immediate answer is that all of them coexist quite happily up on my bookshelves. Moreover, they share a heritage particularly common on my bookshelves, which is that I have no memory of how they got there. Ooh You Were Awful ...But I Like You — the life story of Dick Emery as told to his — count 'em — sixth wife, Fay Hillier — has a reduced sticker from a shop called The Works on it (£15.99 down to £10, then to a further £4.99) and I do have a very vague memory of once being in The Works looking at remaindered books; but actually taking this one to the till, getting the fiver out of my wallet, and rushing home to read Fay's superbly detailed biog of the great man (if a little cursory, perhaps, on the subject of Dick's other five wives) — that's gone. Similarly, I noticed Jimmy Greaves's The Heart of The Game sitting by itself — as if picked out in a Waterstone's recommendation — on my shelves last week, but — perhaps like Jimmy in his drinking days — have no memory of how exactly it ended up there. The Mary Whitehouse book is a tome entitled Whatever Happened to Sex? I'd assumed it was a cri de coeur about the author's personal life, the answer to which, I have to say, is provided by the photo of Mary on the back — but it is, in fact, a learned argument against the permissive society, which, judging from the state of the cover, I rushed out and bought immediately on its publication in 1977, presumably in between buying a new protractor and Never Mind the Bollocks. But I have no memory of doing so. Hitler is a slightly different kettle offish, as I do remember buying most of my Nazi/ Holocaust books, some of which I've had for a while, others that came during the writing of my last novel, set during the war — but what I don't remember is the moment at which these went beyond the standard legal requirement for a North London Jew and became a full-on Hitler/Holocaust library section. Surely there was a moment when I thought: "Hold on... is this becoming a bit creepy? Am I going to be contacted any minute by Stormfront's book club?" But clearly not. It's one of the functions, I think, of being a bit bookish. The fact is, I buy a lot of books, on impulse, I get sent a lot of books, and I hardly ever throw out books — taking the Nazi
A Uf r% rt
hangover a stage further, a part of me feels it's only one step away from book-burning although, actually, I think organising one of those for the Hitler section may be not a bad thing. The trouble is, as one ages, of course, you can't remember why you ever bought half of them. And worse still, you realise that the assumption behind keeping all these books — that you will get round to reading them al one day — is, with time, looking shaky. Will I ever get beyond, for example, just flicking through the photos in Backstage Passes, the biography of Angie Bowie (described as "wickedly funny" by the Atlanta Journal And Constitution)? How heartbreakingly hopefu was it of me to buy Pier Paolo Pasolini's Ragazzi di vita, in the belief that I would one day read it in the original Italian? What am I doing owning a copy of W. E Davies's Make Your Own Fishing Tackle? And presiding over them all, the King, of course, of the Great Unread, The Dauphin of "I'm Definitely Going to Do It One Day", my
much-thumbed, and much put-down, copy of Swann's Way, the first volume of A la recherche du temps perdu. It's a great thing, though. When bored, I can browse through my shelves like a lucky dip. Some books serve as biography, reminding me of mental things about my youth — I have a copy of Mary Cadogan and Patricia Craig's You're A Brick, Angela! (The Girls' Story 1839-1985) because, when I was 11,1 was the youngest member — by about 80 years — ofa society called The Old Boys Book Club, to which Mary (not so sure about Patricia) was also affiliated. And some, like the aforementioned, are just mental. Flicking through Mary Whitehouse's book now I notice a sentence that begins "Alice Cooper, the male 'pop star' is ..." as if the phrase pop star was just some ridiculous affectation, held in quarantine away from Mary's nose by the inverted commas. This makes me want to read the whole thing. I won't, of course. But I won't throw it out either.

Title: New Novels

NEW NOVELS
_d - ..
MR. J. B. MORTON
SKYLIGHTIERS. By J. B. MORTON. (Heine-
rnann. 7s. 6d. net.)
In the interests of his story Mr. J. B. Morton has devised a new religion. Skylight is an English religion for the English.
" Not one blooming rule. That's the whole point of it," says Ephraim Clutch, the moving spirit. ' It's rules and rcegulations that have emptied thlc churches. ... We go about thle place lecturing-not preaching, nmark you. Lecturing. We exhort the young to be cheerful and hopeful. Happiness, that's the keynote. We pass round the plate after our meetings. And so on.-
With the ill-gotten money of Sir George Barlow behind it, Skylight was born. The poor, being fundamentally sensible, rejected it. So a fresh start was made at Oxford, and Skylight was well and truly launched into notoriety. After that it was easily foisted on the frivolous rich. Debate in the Press and among the clergy focused the limelight full on Skylight. But it could not last, as Clutch and his friend Buster Honey had alt along known. Shaken by the genuine conversion of Sir George Barlow, and made aware that the game was up by the displacement of Skylight from the splash page of newspapers, Clutch and his comrade decamped with their substantial %vinnings.
Thus the " religious racket " scored only a temporal victory. MIr. Morton's narrative is lively with mass meetings, processions, and brawls. It is,'indeed, a most hilarious story; but what chiefly matters in it-to him, no doubt, as well as to usis Mr. Nlorton's attitude. Corruption is everywhere, he seems to be saving. There are the silly people who are exploited and the base people who exploit them; and these two classes make up a terribly large part of the England of " Skylighters." Only when life is viewed with a pronounced squint can it appear quite so bad as that.
THE STRANGE INVADERS. By ALUN
LLEWELLYN. (Bell. 7s. 6d. net.)
For his new novel Mr.' Llewellyn has ,gone to -a future period iwhen inan is dying out; and. he has multiplied the causes of his decadence so freely that we cannot ascribe particular effects to any one of them. There is " The Destruction" -familiar to our generation as the next war; in it '; the machines for war destroyed the machines for peace." There is the paralysing creed of the day. This is Stalinism as interpreted by the ruling cliquc which styles itself "'The Fathers " from the study of sacred writings which few of them can read. It is Stalinism without factories, for in culture and knowledge of the crafts man has relapsed into the Llewellyndlithic age. Fortunately for the Fathers enough swords have survived from earlier ages to arm their bodyguard; the people are slaves and unarmed. Nor is this all; there has been some convulsion of Nature that has accentuated the difficulties of humanity. Giant saurians attack the defenceless community. In the conflict and the outcome we have a melodramatic theme which suffices for a thriller ; but we fancv that behind it is an allegory in which the evil forces are Communism, which deprives man of mental initiative, and war typified by the soulless and irresistible saurians.
THE DEMON IN THE HOUSE. Stories of
Tony Morland. By ANGELA THIRKELL. (Hamish Hamilton. 7s. 6d. net.)
" The Demon in the House " is a Christmas prcsent for mothers. Those who read Mrs. Thirkell's "High Rising "will certainlv remember the little boy in it, Tony Morland; she has recognized that in him she had a subject made to her hand, and she now gives us an amplification of the earlier indictment of small-boyhood. Mrs. T'hirkell insists thai she loves as well as hates Tony; and to make this claim credible she, has given most of the brief space between his escapades to the effect 'of them on his mother, Laura-to her anxiety when, for instance, he goes bicycling; to her impulse to resent it when he is being rightly told-off by his outraged elders;'to her fears that he will suffer in " the Upper School " in his nonexistent sensitiveiness; and to her gratitude for an occasional hug. But she is chiefly concerned with the escapades and the objects, including himself, that. as the result of them, have to be cleaned or mended. Not but What his demoniacal quality is exhibited at least as much in what he savs as in what he does. We have it in both aspects when he was told lo have a bath and proceeded to do science: -
Come out at oncc."
But, mother," said Tony, leaping up and down in the water,n sending fresh deluges over the edge with every movement, " this 'is specific gravity. Don't you know specific gravity, mother ? Archimedes discovered it. You filt the bath right up. and then you sit in it, and what comes over the edge is specific gravity."

Author: Null
Title: New Novels
Full_text:
NEW NOVELS
CRIMINAL PSYCHOLOGY
THE POWER To KILL. BY ROBERT
HICHENS. (Benn. 7s. 6d. net.)
Mr. Hichens here gives us yet another of his subtly constructed tales of criminal psychology. The keynote is struck by the remark of a lawyer at a party in the first chapter, that "there are a great many more potential murderers among us than active murderers," because the former do not realize the power they possess. A young American, Clarence Van Drinen, who is listening, displays a curious interest. Is he, perhaps, one of the " potential murderers " ? So far he has only been the victim of an intending murderess, Virginia MacGarron, who in a frenzy of rejected love tried to shoot him before he came to England. Now he is in love with a beautiful but apparently rather frigid Englishwoman, Leila Astlie; but Virginia, who escaped the consequences of her act through his chivalry, is still pursuing him. He marries Leila, but is in the quandary that it is dangerous for him to remain within reach of Virginia's murderous violence, and yet dishonourable to his manhood to seem to run away from her. He compromises by accepting a post at Bale, in Switzerland, and his wife, who had wished him to go with her to the Far East, quickly perceives that this compromise indicates Virginia's power over him; he is a blend of weakness and obstinacy, and his weakness is susceptible to the American woman's impassioned pursuit of him. But Leila now reveals an unsuspected depth of jealous fury. .. and we are still searching for the potential killer who is to turn into an actual one when the shattering climax comes. Mr. Hichens in this clever tale once again shows himself both a born story-teller and a delicate psychologist.
INVASION FROM THE AIR. By FRANIC
McILRAiT and Roy CONNOLLY. (Grayson and Grayson. 7s. 6d. net.)
Destruction of the enemy moral by massed air attack on centres of civilian population is a subject hitherto explored. only in political, military, and technical works. There is a natural disinclination to probe the intimate content of these words, but in this novel, which is a frank and competent piece of anti-war propaganda, the authors have developed in human terms what may happen if the bombing air forces of the great European Powers are not held in check. They give an impressionistic sketch of considerable power of eleven days which elapse between a frontier incident and the armistice to which the crippled nations are driven by the havoc which each wreaks on the other. The Nemesis of a warfare in which the only defence proves to be counter-attack is ruthlessly driven home. The broad effects of Armageddon on masses of men, women and children unarmed, unprotected and untrained in military discipline are worked out in scenes of vivid horror. It may be objected that the characters in this tale are no more than puppets set to dance the consequences of an overstrained premiss. The collapse of the civil power between warring factions of Fascists and Communists in a desolated capital may be overdrawn. None the less, in their imaginative construction of a terrible theme the sharp strokes of this tale are often admirable in their intensity. And as to their applicability to the contemporary scene, he who runs may read.
In addition to the reviews published regularly in The Timtes, full criticisms of new books, together with a comprehensive list of current publications, will be found in The Times Literary Supplemzent, issued every Thursday, price 3d.
