Title: New Novels
Full_text:
NEW NOVELS.
Among new novels are HucC.A's MooR, by Ruth Manning Sanders (Faber and Gwyer, 7s. 6d. net), and Tim Vm.GaE )ocToR, by* Sheila Kaye-Smith (Cassell, 7s. fidi net).
Hucea's Moor will satisfy any readers who care ior.horrors. Except for the character of Deborah, the kind but rather passive housekeeper of the old bedridden miner Bendigo, everything in the novel is horrible. Zeph Wall, the pedlar, deformed
in body and soul, is a scarcely human abortion, driven by his secret revolt against his own hideousness to be the spiteful, bullying beast that he is; old Bendig'o, the dying miner, is partly crazed, and thin'ss only of hiding his worldly goods* from Zeph and his brother; his borother, Thomas Silk, is an avaricious, unctuous hypocrite; and Mabel, Deborah's daughter, aged 26, is a mental deficient. Round the two cottages holding these people spreads the desolation of Hucca's Moor. Author: Null
Title: New Novels
Full_text:
NEW NOVELS
A PRINCE OF THE CAPTIVITY. By JoHN
BUCHAN. (Hodder and Stoughton. 7s. 6d. net).
Mr. Buchan takes for his subject a world out of joint, and for his protagonist a man who, in the hope of setting it right, makes of himself a propitiatory sacrifice. The man, Adam Melfort, is brought to the reader's notice by just the right people in an opening paragraph which will make all good Buchanites wriggle with delighted anticipation. And a page or two later he is doing two years for forgery ! Of course he is innocent-but the book can never be the same afterwards. No one, of course, would know this better than Mr. Buchan. The explanation is that, though he gives us trials of the body in physical adventures too many to enumerate, his subject is trials of the spirit, and these last must include humiliation as well as failure.
We are to suppose that Adam is rehabilitated-at any rate sufficiently for his purposes-by his achievements as a universal Secret Service agent in the War. In the course of them he learned apparently to defy detection when assuming any disguise or speaking any language that the interests of his country demanded. With these accomplishments he was able after the War to move in all social circles and secret societies in this country and Germany. The use to which he put them was to hear the truth about the problems of the day-many of which are most vigorously summarized-and to search for a leader who would inspire the nation with a soul. On the last page he saves the man who may possibly be such a leader at a cost to himself which is implicit in what has gone before.
MRS. RITCHiE. By WILLA MUIR.
(Secker. 7s. 6d. net.)
It has long been orthodox among young authors to thank God they are not as this Pharisee; one regrets, however, that a translator of Mrs. Muir's capacity should take for her second novel so worn a theme as the unpleasantness of the virtuous, and show in handling it such a very docile adherence to tradition. Mrs. Ritchie, who inhabits aScotspre-War town that follows the good old fashion of green shutters, is the domestic despot whose acrid virtues drive.her husband and family to unpleasant ends. The growth and process and effect of these virtues, expounded with an inveterate thoroughness, are the whole substance of the book; and the conventional realism of its lingering detail, expressed throughout in an earnest monotone, comes in the end to the reader's nerves.

Author: Null
Title: New Novels
Full_text:
NEW NOVELS
A VICTORIAN ROMANCE
THE FROZEN HEART. By MRS. ST. LOE
STRACHEY. (Dent. 7s. 6d.)
This, Mrs. St. Loe Strachey's first novel, might be called a domestic historical romance. Her heroine Margaret Russell is in the schoolroom at Queen Victoria's accession and we leave her as -a happy married woman, after many trials, in 1870. Mrs. Strachey has drawn largely ;on contemporary memoirs for the atmosphere and surroundings of her characters; the Corn Laws are discussed with the dilettantism of the drawing-room, the railway is gradually accepted, we see a London season in the forties, Mario and Grisi, the still powerful Almacks Committee, the riding parties in the Row. Then the scene shifts to Paris in 1848, where Margaret is carried away by a romantic feeling for Lamartine.
The affair does not go beyond sentiment, but poor Margaret's happiness is ruined for years by what her brother quite truly calls Lamartine's exploiting of her generous nature. Even riches and marriage with a faithful and high-minded admirer do not thaw her frozen heart. She hears of Lamartine in distress and is able, through her husband's tact, to send money to him unknown. At last the news of the Commune, the burning of Paris, suddenly break down her pride. Her childhood is charmingly drawn and her worldly mother and her Foreign Office brother, bent on consolidating his position and distrusting all poets, are convincing characters.
As I LAY DYING. BY WILLIAM FAULKNER.
(Chatto and Windus. 7s. 6d.)
In "As I Lay Dying" Mr. Faulkner tells how a " poor white " farmer fulfils his wife's wish that her body should be buried in her native town, many miles away. Annie Bundren dies, her son Cash has made her coffin, and the wagon is to start with the whole family for Jefferson as soon as it returns from carrying one more load. Anse Bundren is an unlucky man, and a helpless one, too, but selfish, obstinate, and a wonderful borrower. His luck is against him from the beginning of this trip, for the rains come on, the wagon is late back, and the only bridge over the river has been washed away in the interval. They attempt the ford and get the wagon across, but the mules are lost and Cash's broken leg is broken again.
But with another team the wretched pilgrimage creaks on-Cash with his leg fixed in cement laid on without grease, yet hardly complaining as gangrene sets in; Darl, his brother, gradually turning crazy, and the sister, Dewy Dell, turning over and over in her mind the fact that she is pregnant. Darl sets a barn on fire, so as to burn the coffin and give immediate rest to his mother's bones, but Jewel, after helping to save the animals, snatches the coffin from the flames and stumbles, burning himself, into the open. And the wretched cortege goes on to the end, each character telling a piece of its history and the thoughts with which he or she follows it. The whole is a piece of tapestry composed with enormous skill; but whether the spectacle of human misery and folly is as exclusively important as the author seems to believe is somewhat doubtful.
SUSIE'S" CAIREER. BY ROBERT HICHENS.
(Cassell. 8s. 6d.)
Mr. Robert Hichens never ceases to be a skilful dramatist, and the outstanding feature of " Susie's " Career is that it was a vivid and dramatic affair in the picturesque setting of an opera singer's life in Cairo, Paris, and Marseilles. There is a philosophic question raised too: the conffict between an artisfs career and the claims of personal affection and passion. But perhaps Suzanne Blythe, the American girl with the crystalline voicc but cold and unawakened nature, held in strict tutelage by a domineering mother, is too immature or too temperamentally frigid to offer a fair field for the battle to be fought out. She is tempted by the mysterious Mme. Pangalos, who is staying in the same hotel near the Sphinx and the Pyramids, to engage in an adventure with the young Viennese Baron Cora, who is a vital but shallow and cruel egotist; and part of the adventure, which has a symbolic value and is thrillingly described, is a perilous ascent of the Great Pyramid in the dark. This means a compromised reputation and ultimately a breach with her possessive mother. The trials that follow have a deepening effect on Susie the artist; their consequences for her life must be left for the author's own adroit development.

Author: Null
Title: New Novels
Full_text:
NEW NOVELS.
"TTHE JUDGE."
T= JUDGE. By REBECCA WEST.
(Hutchinson.. 7s. 6d. . net.)
Miss Rebecca West has spoiled a brilliant story and a brilliant study of character with the overlaying mutter of morbid and gloomy theories. "The Judge" has two parts, whereof the first is not alone pleasant, -but artistic also the second not merely disagreeable, but heavy. The little Edinburgh " flapper " of the opening, with her ardent feminism and democratic ideals, at once an intellectual and the simplest of children, is charmingly and wittily presented. We have come to love Ellen Melville and her romantic lover by the time she turns her back on Edinburgh, her mother dead, and goes to visit his mother in Essex.
It is then that the theories begin to push in. Richard Yaverland, her betrothed, is an illegitimate child. His niother was seduced by the squire and pelted and mobbed in the village street in "the good old way " before he was born. The main theory appears to be, judging from the title-page, that every mother is a judge who sentences the children for the sins of the father. That, to begin with, is, we believe, false. But, such as it is, the theory does not seem to be carried out logically. Marion Yaverland has been sinned against by the fathers of both her sons. Her predominant sentiment, however, appears to be jealousy of the girl who has won the heart of the best-beloved. Passions rise in this strange and repellent family. till at the last the mother commits suicide, her miserable life rendered unbearable by the prospect of losing Richard to another woman, and Richard quietly plants the bread-knife in his worthless brother's heart.
This sounds ridiculous. In Mliss West's very capable hands it is far from ridiculous. It is powerful but it is also illogical, disconnected. There is none of the inevitability which the Russians would have put into a.tragedy of the sort.

Author: J. S.
Title: New Novels
Full_text:
NEW' NOVELÂ§
WAYS OF ESCAPE
No apology need now be given for what are called, ' rather slightingly, " escape ' stories, and it is only a question what sort of "escape" is likely to be most effective. There are the more obvious sort, represented here very efficiently by Mr. Francis Brett Young's twenty-sixth novel, and the less obvious, the escape into the past, of which TixmE'S HARVEST, by Dorothy Charques (Hamish lHamilton, 9s.), is a very good example. That Mrs. Charques's output is small is not surprising. Her craftsmanship is admirable, and she manages to write with care withotit killing the apparent spontaneity bf her story. This time it is of Englisi cotintry life a htindred years ago, with a military interlude in Afglianistan, and particularly of Jos Htill, the brewer's unwvanted son, and his love for a farmers daughter. What is embarrassing in some bucolic pieces is absent here. These are sturdy and irregular figures, neither idealized nor niade conventionally earthy, and the Reform agitations and a host of country events and political occasions test their responses to otlier things besides lovemaking. In short, it is a book with character, dignity, and ilhe sense of humour implied in aI SenIse of proportion.
Mr. Youngls MR. LuCrON's FREEDOM (H-leinemann. 9s. 6d.) hias its own merits. Mr. Lucton is a business man wlho comes to see, like Mfr. Maugham's breadwinner, that his family has no other use for him, and he, too, takes to his heels. Mis flight takes him into an English countryside that is partly Mr. Priestley's and partly Jefiery Farnol's, and in this he discovers for himself the delights of working and wandering in the open air and finds adventures everywhere. This is much more wxhat is meant by the novel of " escape," and, to be honest, it is possible to see the objection to it. To eseape so purposefully, wvith so Imlucl artifice, is hardly to escape at all. Yet this school of writers has a great store of plots, a qutick eye for the effectively, and perhaps truly, rural, and a charming philosophy of reasstirance and consolation.
J. S.

Author: Null
Title: New Novels
Full_text:
NEW NOVELS.
THE WAR; HISTORICAL
FICTION.
Among this week's novels are TEN YEARs AGO, by R. H. M;ottram (Chatto and Windus, 5s. net) ; THE PAsHwAY, by Henry Williamson (Capo, 7s. 6d. net); UNDEBxEATIH, by C. E. Lawrence (Mlurray, 7s. 6d. net); and DEFEAT, by Ricarda Huch, translated by Mrs. Alison Phillips (Knopf, 10s. 6d. net).
On the eve of the tenth anniversary of the Armistice Mr. R. H. Mottram has collected in " Ten Years Ago " a series of stories or sketches dealing with the War. Some of them are topical articles, such as one called "Never Again ! " evidently: written for the unveiling of the Menin Gate memorial, and the majority have already appeared in newspapers or reviews; but almost all bear reproduction very well. The best, " The Common Secretary " and " The Flemish Border," treating of that part of the battle zone which their author has made peculiarly his own, are very good indeed. The Flemish peasant, his surroundings, and the Austro-Spanish traditions of his countryside seem to have entered into Mr. Mottrarn's blood, and he paints them all with as much skill in a hasty sketch as in a full-length canvas. The quality of those more directly connected with the machinery of warfare varies. "The Chink," a study of Chinese labourers at the front, is excellent. " The Devil's Own," a fantastic story of a terrible phantom ambulance car, which runs amok and slays men upon the roads, seems on the other hand to miss fire. It is the sort of thing that some other writers of no greater general accomplishment could make blood-curdling, but it does not belong to what seems to be Mr. Mottram's true vein-the pi esentation of things seen and of their effect upon the wTiter's mind. Perhaps the most vivid of all is " One Day in Every Year," a record of the thoughts and remembrances that came to him duting the Two Minutes' Silence of 1927.
Mr. Henry Williamson, whose " Tarka the Otter " was recently awarded the Hawthornden Prize, has written a remarkable novel, of which the hero appears to be intended to be a reincarnation of Shelley in post-War Devon. We first meet him when he settles himself upon a family of three generations living impoverished and servantless in an old manor-house, and the story ends with his death by drowning. Between these two incidents there is no plot in the conventional sense, but simply a record of William Maddison's opinions and of his relations with three girls. That is not to say that there is any lack of liveliness in the narrative, while those who know this author's other work will be delighted by his descriptions of wild life and North Devon scenery. Nor is Maddison's idealisni and fierce rebellion against cruelty in any form ever less than inter. esting. Mr. Williamson appears generally in sympathy wit.h his philosophy-which might be called Christian C6mmunism. Hev will be regarded according to the reader's temperament and convictions ; to some, doubtless, he will appear a Christlike figure, to others nmerely a pathetically beautiful soul flawed by weaknesses and even absurdities. Yet the second class, even if it is the larger, will agree with the first that Mr. Williamson's conception is original and that he has lived up to its standard in his execution. Think what we will of MIaddison, we are not like to forget him in a hurry.
MIr. C. E. Lawrence's " Underneath " is to all intents a moral tract, and it has the particular defeet of tracts-namely, that in its desire to describe a particular process of moral regeneration it is both arbitrary and improbable as fiction. Gerald Alorreys is young and well-to-do, but dissatisfied with himself and with life. He needs a hard task to carry out by his own strength alone. He therefore sets himself the foolish task of spending a whole year as an outcast, living only on what he can earn by casual labour, though without any experience in casual labouring. He has a rough time, as might be expected, but the account of it. upon which the author expends a good deal of emotion, is undramatic because the hero's purpose is so indefinite, and, for a young man who has served in the Army, he shows but poor intelligence. Towards the end, when Gerald is described as descending into the lowvest depths of despair and exhaustion in searching for a prostitute whom he had nursed quixotically back to health, MIr. Lawrence writes as if he were describing the penance of a saint, which is slightly ridiculous, since the hero's aim was to acquire knowledge, not to mortify the body. The book ends with marriage and stereotyped sentiments.
Fraulein Huch's " Defeat,', the latest of a series of historical novels fr6m Germany, is, like some novels and more histories not quite fiction and not quite historical. The method employed is such as to leave the reader doubtful both of the author's intention and of her focus of interest. The story of Garibaldi's defence of Rome in 1848 is told now in pages of dry summary, now in short personal anecdotes, and the total effect suggests a pastiche of the classical writers who did not yet distinguish between history and romance. Friiulein Huch has apparently wished to paint a great picture with many figures, but has not succeeded in giving much, or any significant, life to any one in the whole group. She tells us about her persons, Garibaldi, Ugo Bassi, Nino Bixio, and the rest, but she hardly ever makes them show themselves to us. The experiment is interesting-with so sensitive and experienced a writer it could not have been otherwise-but it is a failure. It is neither one thing nor the other ; it has neither the articulated bones of history nor the warm flesh of fiction, and, uneasily balanced between the two, it is only in brief moments that it exhibits a precarious passion.

Lawrence (Mlurray, 7s. 6d. net); and DEFEAT, by Ricarda Huch, translated by Mrs. Alison Phillips (Knopf, 10s. 6d. net). On the eve of the tenth anniversary of the Armistice Mr. R. H. Mottram has collected in " Ten Years Ago " a series of stories or sketches dealing with the War. Some of them are topical articles, such as one called "Never Again ! " evidently: written for the unveiling of the Menin Gate memorial, and the majority have already appeared in newspapers or reviews; but almost all bear reproduction very well. The best, " The Common Secretary " and " The Flemish Border," treating of that part of the battle zone which their author has made peculiarly his own, are very good indeed. The Flemish peasant, his surroundings, and the Austro Spanish traditions of his countryside seem to have entered into Mr. Mottrarn's blood, and he paints them all with as much skill in a hasty sketch as in a full length canvas. The quality of those more directly connected with the machinery of warfare varies. "The Chink," a study of Chinese labourers at the front, is excellent. " The Devil's Own," a fantastic story of a terrible phantom ambulance car, which runs amok and slays men upon the roads, seems on the other hand to miss fire. It is the sort of thing that some other writers of no greater general accomplishment could make blood curdling, but it does not belong to what seems to be Mr. Mottram's true vein the pi esentation of things seen and of their effect upon the wTiter's mind. Perhaps the most vivid of all is " One Day in Every Year," a record of the thoughts and remembrances that came to him duting the Two Minutes' Silence of 1927. Mr. Henry Williamson, whose " Tarka the Otter " was recently awarded the Hawthornden Prize, has written a remarkable novel, of which the hero appears to be intended to be a reincarnation of Shelley in post War Devon. We first meet him when he settles himself upon a family of three generations living impoverished and servantless in an old manor house, and the story ends with his death by drowning. Between these two incidents there is no plot in the conventional sense, but simply a record of William Maddison's opinions and of his relations with three girls. That is not to say that there is any lack of liveliness in the narrative, while those who know this author's other work will be delighted by his descriptions of wild life and North Devon scenery. Nor is Maddison's idealisni and fierce rebellion against cruelty in any form ever less than inter. esting. Mr. Williamson appears generally in sympathy wit.h his philosophy which might be called Christian C6mmunism. Hev will be regarded according to the reader's temperament and convictions ; to some, doubtless, he will appear a Christlike figure, to others nmerely a pathetically beautiful soul flawed by weaknesses and even absurdities. Yet the second class, even if it is the larger, will agree with the first that Mr. Williamson's conception is original and that he has lived up to its standard in his execution. Think what we will of MIaddison, we are not like to forget him in a hurry. MIr. C. E. Lawrence's " Underneath " is to all intents a moral tract, and it has the particular defeet of tracts namely, that in its desire to describe a particular process of moral regeneration it is both arbitrary and improbable as fiction. Gerald Alorreys is young and well to do, but dissatisfied with himself and with life. He needs a hard task to carry out by his own strength alone. He therefore sets himself the foolish task of spending a whole year as an outcast, living only on what he can earn by casual labour, though without any experience in casual labouring. He has a rough time, as might be expected, but the account of it. upon which the author expends a good deal of emotion, is undramatic because the hero's purpose is so indefinite, and, for a young man who has served in the Army, he shows but poor intelligence. Towards the end, when Gerald is described as descending into the lowvest depths of despair and exhaustion in searching for a prostitute whom he had nursed quixotically back to health, MIr. Lawrence writes as if he were describing the penance of a saint, which is slightly ridiculous, since the hero's aim was to acquire knowledge, not to mortify the body. The book ends with marriage and stereotyped sentiments. Fraulein Huch's " Defeat,', the latest of a series of historical novels fr6m Germany, is, like some novels and more histories not quite fiction and not quite historical. The method employed is such as to leave the reader doubtful both of the author's intention and of her focus of interest. The story of Garibaldi's defence of Rome in 1848 is told now in pages of dry summary, now in short personal anecdotes, and the total effect suggests a pastiche of the classical writers who did not yet distinguish between history and romance. Friiulein Huch has apparently wished to paint a great picture with many figures, but has not succeeded in giving much, or any significant, life to any one in the whole group. She tells us about her persons, Garibaldi, Ugo Bassi, Nino Bixio, and the rest, but she hardly ever makes them show themselves to us. The experiment is interesting with so sensitive and experienced a writer it could not have been otherwise but it is a failure. It is neither one thing nor the other ; it has neither the articulated bones of history nor the warm flesh of fiction, and, uneasily balanced between the two, it is only in brief moments that it exhibits a precarious passion.

Author: May, Derwent
Title: Blossoming on the bookshelves
Full_text:
Blossoming on the bookshelves
As Springwatch returns to BBC Two on Monday, Derwent May grabs his butterfly net and deerstalker to go in search of the finest new nature books
M WATSON/ARDEA; DAVID TIPLING/PHOTOLIBRARY * Nature in all its glory, clockwise from far left: amatungula and morning glory; flamingos in flight; robins enjoy a good reputation in print Below: a Great Crested Grebe
IF KATE HUMBLE is once again trying to curb Bill Oddie's bubbling erotic imagination, it must be spring — or at any rate it must be Springwatch on BBC Two. Either way, it is a timely moment to see what new nature books are in the shops. Starting at the garden door, Dominic Couzens has written a sequel to his RSPB book Secret Lives of Garden Birds, this one called Secret Lives of Garden Wildlife (Helm, £14.99/offer £13.49). So this time we do not get birds from the RSPB, but plenty of entertaining tales of other creatures — male spiders strumming tunes on female spiders' webs, foxes going crazy over shoes left in the garden, and hedgehogs regularly tossing a coat of spittle over their spines with their tongue, for a reason no zoologist has ever been able to explain. David Lack, the great ornithologist who was the first expert on robin behaviour, also compiled a little literary anthology called Robin Redbreast. His son, Andrew Lack, has expanded this into a longer book with a shorter title, Redbreast (SMH, £19.95/no discount), and has found some wonderful robins, mainly in poetry. They are mostly seen as good birds. There are several accounts of them covering the babes in the wood with leaves — one with good colour sense using strawberry leaves. Other robins comfort prisoners — or unhappy monks — at their cell windows. Ted Hughes gives his robin a "flaming shirt". Emily Bronte puts her finger on a paradox of the robin's song when she calls it "wildly tender" (just like her novel?), while Edward
Thomas brings out another paradox when he writes of the robin's "sad songs of autumn mirth". A new identification book to birds, by Marc Duquet, is called Birds By Colour (Helm, £12.99/£11.69). Wild flower guides are often arranged by colour, so why not birds? This one sets about the task imaginatively, with categories such as "Birds with a black throat" and "Birds with a black cheek". The only problem is that one cannot hold birds in the hand like flowers, so one may not even notice these features. Also, birds can look very different colours in different lights. Black crows can even look white when sunlight bounces off them. Nevertheless a good try, with good pictures. Where do all the flowers in our gardens come from? An excellent new book, Flower Hunters by Mary and John Gribbin (Oxford, £16.99/£15.29), tells the story of 11 botanists who travelled far in search of new flowers and trees. Joseph Banks went with Captain Cook on his first voyage round the world, and Botany Bay was named by Cook in honour of all the plants that Banks found there, including mimosas, acacias and eucalyptus. Banks also discovered jasmines and gardenias in Tahiti. Others include Joseph Hooker, who found rhododendrons and
In our min the flamin marg th in salt lakes, so that if they neck out f * already in ?^*V'(i& territory. - - -**'"" rtiingo Ho
magnolias in the Himalayas, and David Douglas, who after nightmarish adventures in the North American snow sent back the first seeds of the Douglas fir to Europe. The Gribbins also include the great Swede, Linnaeus, who as a boy was already making lists of his toys. He travelled for new plants only as far as Lapland, but his mind travelled around the whole plant creation, setting up a classification that endures to this day. He also made a flower clock, with the opening and closing of the different flowers telling the time — and this book tells us how to do it.
!Robins comfort unhappy monks and prisoners at cell windows1
The Greater Flamingo by Alan Johnson and Frank Cezilly (Poyser, £40/£36), is a thoroughly scientific study of this beautiful and amazing bird, but from its learned words there rise the most striking images. mind's eye we see flamingos of the. Camargue sitting on their mud nests the shallow close together stretch their full their head is the next bird's We see the flaHocks marching
along, then all throwing back their great pink wings simultaneously — perhaps to help them to synchronise their activities, perhaps just to show off to potential mates. We see tha hundreds of chicks clustering on the salt for protection, as close as a swarm of bees, when their parents have all flown away to find food for them. We can also learn about the the hard work that has gone into trying to save these flamingos. Meanwhile, Lost Land ofthe Dodo by Anthony Cheke and Julian Hume (Poyser, £45/£40.50) focuses on the home of a famous bird that is lost for ever. This is the Mascarene Islands, which consist of Mauritius, Reunion and Rodrigues. It is where, at the end of the 16th century, Europeans found the dodo, that strange, flightless bird, and where before the end of the 17th century it was extinct. Probably the main culprits were the pigs, introduced by the Dutch, that ate its eggs. But many other creatures have vanished from the islands since then, including the giant tortoises that the settlers ate, and this scholarly book gives a full, devastating account of them. There are delightful paintings by Julian Hume of other extinct birds — such as the raven parrot, Commerson's lizard-owl and the pigeon hollandais. This book also gives a moving and instructive account of what is being done to save the wildlife still found on the islands.

Author: Graham, Andrew
Title: Books
Full_text:
6 le WA
The best concise general work for the winelover's bookshelf is the Penguin Book of Wines by Allan Sichel (1965, Penguin Books, 6s.). It distils a lifetime's knowledge, and was written by a man who weighed his words. Apart from prices quoted for wines, little is out of date.
I warmly recommend the following books, chosen from a wide field:
The Wines of Bordeaux, by Edmund Penning-RowseJl (1969. Michael Soseph, 55s.). A scholarly book covering the subject p detail.
T7ze Wines of Burgundy, by H.. W. Yoxall (1968. Michael Joseph, 30s.). Ibess exhaustive than the Bordeaux book, it gives all the information needed by most people.
Champagne, by Patrick Forbes (1967. Gollancz, 70s.).
Mr. Forbes knows the subject from A to Z and writes well.
Portuguese Wine, by Raymond Postgate (1969. J. M. Dent, 25s). A scholarly, short book.
Sherry, by Julian Jcffs (Faber & Faber, new edition due January, 1971, 50s.). The standard work.
The Wines of Italy, by Cyril Ray, eminently readable and -well-informed, now only available in Wines of the World (1967. McGraw Hill, 105s.). This volume also contains
carefully compiled books on European wvines not mentioned above,, and on wines of ot,her countries.
Wines and Spirits- of the World (Editor: Alec Gold. Virtue, 140s.) is another good compendium.
Wine by Hiugh Johnson (1968. Sphere Paperbacks, 1 5s.). A book to consult when you want advice or to browse over when you feel the need for civilized writing urnimpeded by technical terms.
For further, reading see the chapter on that'sabject in the Penguin b6ok.mentioned. Wherc items in Sichel's selection. are out of print. I know no better obtainer of second-hand books than Heywood' Hill, 10, Curzon Street, W.I..
Andrew Graham

Author: muir, kate
Title: Cheerless mourning
Full_text:
Cheerless mourning
NOT a cheerful novel, Oblivi - on , but then Josephine Hart has never taken much interest in the comfort of her readers. Instead she lusts for their squirming discomfort . Her taste for the Gothic underbelly of the conventional is well - known . Her preferred topics are hatred, erotic obsession and betrayal. Hart's severe writing style became notorious after her first two books, Damage and Sin. In Oblivion, the text is picked so clean of adjectives
and subordinate clauses that only a skeleton remains. This is appropriate , of course, for a book about death. Although encased in a plot about a media-type coming to terms with mourning his wife, Laura, Oblivion is in fact a variegated meditation on death, grief and remem - brance . Placed curiously in the centre of the novel is an 80 - page play in which different dead characters give mono - logues about their lives, their manner of dying, and their
B OBLIVION By Josephine Hart Vintage , £5.99 desire to keep an emotional hold on the living. Laura's husband cannot get her out of his mind even as he approaches orgasm in the bed of another woman months later . Her mother writes a private diary of grief in which she confesses that she fasts and has imagined seances with Laura. She cannot com - p reh e n d that Laura's husband wants to live a normal life, and she bitterly spies on him with his new girlfriend. Later, as the blurb notes, we discover "the living must be ruthless to survive". Indeed one character advises: " Hap - piness is a decision. Make it.
And don't cry." Hart 's decision to tackle mourning in all its facets is daring: bestselling novels are rarely so bleak. The unconven - tional structure of the book is harder to take. Why would a middle-class widow write her diary in pared-down Haftian style ? Why do the characters talk in staccato sentences? Vintage has just reissued all three novels with stylish cover portraits of veiled and ban - daged women , presumably to indicate the themes of emo - tional injury and double lives. The books are best read with breaks in between, for a trilogy of cold portraits of the chattering classes who lack a sense of humour can hardly be stomached without recourse to Prozac .
Kate Muir

Author: Gordon, Giles
Title: Hard back of the market
Full_text:
BOOKS Giles Gordon
Hard back of the market
I Bloomsbury editors and de - signers have deliberately es - chewed the current trend for | making books larger and set out to make them smaller but physically mouthwatering. The books are mostly priced at less than a tenner and, in the case of the longer titles, verging towards the chunky. They occupy less space than most paperbacks, which is a relief if your bookshelves are as crammed as mine. They also use less paper and cloth, which saves money. You have every confidence that there is a discriminating editor be - hind the series. The books are not being brought out merely because they are available but because someone cares about them. It is worth making the point that the Bloomsbury Classics (I'm not sure about the title unless there are more I "classic" authors currently churning out books than I'd £ realised) and the chaste, 5 white-covered Everyman IA - 1 brary books are doing well in thp chnn« ft is alsn u/nrth
ONE OF the most elegant, roomy and relaxed bookshops in London is Daunts in Marylebone High Street. It specialises in travel books and guides but has a selection of new general books at the front to entice passers-by . Any reader of this column is likely to be an habitue of bookshops and thus will know how to respond to the goodies set out. He or she, perhaps through a lifetime's practice, should be able instinctively to assess which books appeal, and which don't merit a second glimpse. I was tempted by Lord Goodman 's memoirs but, having perused the index, I left well alone. I was also tempted by David Frost's memoirs but it wasn't the whole life, only the early years. Admittedly I was killing time, putting in ten minutes before going to an appointment nearby. But this is the way most people use bookshops. If I set out consciously to spend time in a bookshop the result is likely to make inroads on my wallet. Yet if you are an inexperienced visitor to bookshops, you may panic at the multiplicity of titles on display and retreat fast, not sure how to react. Do you pick the things up and look through them, or do you just admire the set of titles? As I was about to leave the shop, my eyes fell on a display of the stunningly attractive little Bloomsbury Classics. I possess a few of these sturdily cloth-bound , lusciously jac - keted (designed by Jeff Fisher) titles, but my back must have been turned when Blooms - bury infiltrated more on to the market. They are, mostly, reprints of newish books
by living authors (Jeanette Winterson, Paul Bailey, Julian Barnes, Tobias Wolff, Mar - garet Atwood, Janet Frame and Michael Ondaatje are all there) which were allowed by their original publishers to go out of print before their time, or have simply ceased to be available in hardback, as if hardbacks are dinosaurs; but what, in these Jurassic Park days, is more alive than dinosaurs? I wrote a few weeks ago about how unprepossessing most new hardbacks are — with computer typesetting printed grey on paper which soon turns brown at the edges. The Bloomsbury Classics, sharply printed by Butler & Tanner on a cream antique paper, are fulfilling the kind of demand which Penguins did in the heyday of Sir Allen Lane's miraculous bird. It is as if the
commenting that they are extraordinary value compared with the paperbacks of last year's hardback, which this year tend to provide little change from £7. The reason, inflation apart, why paper - backs are costing more is because fewer people are buying them. The blockbuster bestsellers are, no doubt, doing as well as ever, but everything else, fiction and non - fiction , is selling less. Five thousand is regarded as a respectable paperback sale: it used to be 20,000. It costs but a few pence to manufacture a paperback, provided you're able to print and sell vast quantities. Hence, historically, the almost giveaway price of paperbacks. Ironically, certain publishers, led by Reed, believing that there is consumer resistance to high prices, are experimenting with pricing new hardbacks down, and their prices are competitive with paperbacks. Adrian Mole: The Wilderness Years, for instance, is £8.99, £1 cheaper than Sue Townsend's previous book. Would it be reckless to predict the death of the paperback? It won't happen overnight but it could be a lingering, protracted affair. Mass-market paperback publishers may have shot themselves in the foot by producing objects which, once you start reading them, are about as inviting as the telephone directory but more fuzzily printed. As the book reading population grows older, it will increasingly welcome the re-emergence of handsomely produced hardbacks.

Author: J. S.
Title: New Novels
Full_text:
NEW NOVELS
GRANNY AND THE BORCKS
THY ROD AND THY STAFF. By HJALMAR
BERGMAN. Translated by CLAUDE
NAPIER. Cape. 7s. 6d.
FINE ROMANCE. By HUGH P. McGRAW.
Heinemann. 7s. 6d.
SPREAD No WINGS. BY ULRIC NISBET.
Fortune Press. 7s. 6d.
THE SILVER LAND. By J. M. Scorr.
Hodder and Stoughton. 7s. 6d.
There are many possible relationships with God. Looking back on her life, old Granny Borck, in Mr. Bergman's novel, talks to Him, blustering and cajoling through the long nights just as she had done with her family and the Borcks in general for the last 50 years. For Granny Borck had had to make her way in the world by craft. Somewhere in the sixties she decided that her father's cottage in a Swedish village was not enough for her and set off for town in a milkeart. It was not the most promising beginning for a career, but Agnes had determination and the cunning of the peasant, and the first person she saw was Jonathan Borck, one of the curious clan who individually might be bakers, merchants, impoverished nobility, petty officials, or failures more or less disguised but who held together and supported one another in their difficulties until the family became the wonder and admiration of the town. She saw him, she admired his grand stone house with the copper roof that brought him almost to bankruptcy, she married him, and she set out to save him from the depredations of the clan.
A CHARACTER FOR AN ACTRESS
The charm of THY ROD AND THY STAFF is that it presents a truthful account of human nature with something of a fairytale decoration. Granny Borck has her children, her grandchildren, her petty triumphs, and sorrows that now begin to fade into the uncertainty of an old woman's recollections. She beat her son Gabriel's seducer but took the child into her house. She was devoted to Gabrieloddly and shamefully devoted to him-and she demolished the shame with humour. She was not with him when he dicd since she believed he preferred his father to herself, and in one grand scene of alternating victory and defeat at the end of the book she learns from her other children, together with much else that had not occurred to her before, that Gabriel supposed she only meant to dominate him. Perhaps the most illuminating thing to be said of this fresh and original novel is that, in a careful adaptation, it would make the perfect play for Miss Edith Evans.
Where the old can afford to look back tolerantly on life, it is too much to expect the young, who are still in the thick of it, to be either patient or humorous. Their impulse is rather to act than to reflect, and even when they are as conceited and cautious as young Denis Byrne at the start of FINE ROMANCE sooner or later they find themselves slipping into movement. Young Byrne's slip is towards marriage with the most beautiful of typists in his mother's office, and, altogether forgetting the caution proper in a man entirely dependent on his mother, he flouts her, leaves home, and goes to live among the curious family of the Latimerf~ somewhere in a distant suburb of London. If the Borcks are clannish the Latimers can only be said to coalesce like tapioca after boiling. Even the lovely Sylvia, who has a Puritan tongue and a heart pledged only to the main chance, enjoys this constant jovial dropping-in of aunts, cousins, and their young men on the household over the greengrocer's, and it is as much fear of being absorbed into the Latimers as failing infatuation for Sylvia that induces Denis at length to make a bid for freedom with his mother. The novel as a whole is an interesting English version of the American "hard-boiled" story, and Mr. McGraw deals shrewdly and wittily with class distinctions among people who have only that, or pleasure, or * getting on," to talk about.
THE CLERK AND EGERIA
SPREAD No WINGS is also of the suburbs but is less frivolous. The clerk in it has aspirations to poetry and several handicaps in the shape of a wife and two small children. Miss Empson, the cashier at the butcher's, is his Egeria, half guardian angel and half governess, leading him in the right paths of Beauty-the capital is Mr. Nisbet's-by way of the National Gallery and Candide. What is to come of all this culture hastily grafted on to a way of life in which the office and the villa home are supreme'? In Mr. Nisbet's case not very much, unless you count the gradual emergence of the wife, who first was appalled at the nude in painting, to be a Lower Slapton deminiondaine. But the earnestness of the story, when-it is not being mildly and funnily improper, is at least true to life. Half the anonymous lives one dismisses so easily as dull and made to pattern are redeemed by aspiration. Thev are untutored, not insensitive, and in this story of the little clerk to whom nothing important happens but a change of work and a change of loves-to him they are, of course, more important than anything else in the world -Mr. Nisbet keeps to the truth of the matter, the terror of the employer, the fear of convention, and the rare excitcment of conversing for the first time about books and painting, capital letters and all.
Our last is very youthful indeed, but none the less interesting for that, since if Mr. Scott fills his romance with explorers he cannot verv well leave out Eskimo customs, which make better reading. THE SILVER LAND is the east coast of Greenland, to which a little party of amateur explorers venture in search of an undiscovered tribe of which they have got wind. It opens-though the narrator is apologetic-with a Rugby match, and the game is the key to the story. Geoffrey Troy, explorer, Rory Anderson, an unworldly Scottish baronet, Fielding Jones, a scien-
tist, Jeremy. an undergraduate, and.Starlight, an advertising agent-they are all decent fellows, and the drama is dependent rather on Eskimo responses to lack of food and other tribulations of the wilderness than to any divisions among the Europeans. What holds the attention in the book is the constitution of the Eskimo society, a perfect Communisnn with only such drawbacks as the compulsory removal of the old or inefficient when society can do with them no longer, and Eskimo methods of hunting, amusement, and surviving the long winter. For those who have still to find an edifying present for a boy Mr. Scott's unsentimental varn should he a cafe choice.
J. S.

has returned.to the 18th-century setting of an earlier bestseller, Chatterton. , Mingling fact and fiction to entirely plausible effect, The Lambs of London is set in the mid-1790s, when Charles Lamb, then a few years into what was to be a 30-year career at the East India Company, was recovering from a nervous breakdown. Nursing him was his beloved sister, Mary — herself on the verge of the fit of insanity that was td cause her, a year or two later, to murder their mother. Among the other characters who people this vividly realised world is the antiquarian bookseller and sometime forger William Ireland. The platonic but intense romance between the latter and Mary Lamb is the focus of the story, which ends — as, indeed, does the love affair — when Ireland is unmasked as a fraud and Mary, distracted by grief, commits the terrible crime for which she remains notorious. The author's re-creation of these events is masterly. His feeling for the language of his chosen period is as sharp as one has come to expect. But it is in the realisation of the characters — poor, troubled Mary and her dipsomaniac sibling; gifted, over-reaching Ireland, and a host of others — that Ackroyd excels. Tender, funny and humane, this is as good as anything he has written.
THE LAMBS OF LONDON by Peter Ackroyd Vintage, £6.99 El £6.64 (free p&p) Ackroyd's wonderful novel continues what seems to have become a lifetime's exploration of London's past. After Clerkenwell Tales, which was set in medieval London, he
»,'V**Pjj" hjtfjhjftfl.liliih frMMiUf'i
p Head-hunted by PopCo, a multinational toy company, she is at first enthusiastic about her job, devising problem-solving games for nine-year-olds, which enables her to reconnect with her own unconventional childhood. But then she is asked to participate in a top-secret project aimed at teenage girls. Gradually, she starts to understand the insidious nature of PopCo's marketing strategy, and to realise that she no longer wants to be part of it. While some interesting points are made about the way that children have been inveigled by big business into becoming avid consumers, the novel is more than just a timely anti-capitalist rant. Full of cryptograms, digressions on treasure hunting, the politics of vegetarianism, and code-breaking lore, it offers much more subtle pleasures. The best thing, in fact, is the character of Alice — a self-confessed "geek" with a fondness for mathematical theorems, homoeopathy, and stylishly unstylish clothes. Brought up to prefer books to television, and ideas to fashion, she feels like an outsider in a materialist world. Like an escaper from an Iris Murdoch novel unaccountably caught up in a Douglas Coupland plot, it is she who keeps the reader reading on when the worthy rhetoric begins to pall.
POPCO by Scarlett Thomas HarperPerennial, £7.99 El £7.59 (free p&p) Thomas's enjoyably cultish novel on the evils of globalisation is narrated by Alice, the descendant of Bletchley Park code-breakers and a professional setter of crossword puzzles.

Here, as in her earlier books, the ups and downs of relationships are dissected, and the improbability of true love ever running smooth is wryly pointed up. When 19-year-old Vince meets shy, beautiful Joy on a Norfolk campsite, it seems as if his problems with girls are over. But then the couple are separated by one of those misunderstandings so common in this kind of fiction, and don't meet again until years later, by which time both are on the verge of getting married to someone else. Nor is this the end of their troubles. A possessive husband, an ill-timed pregnancy and a certain mutual inertia seem likely to keep them apart indefinitely. Fortunately, help is at hand in the form of a psychic cat... ' Like all romantic comedies, Vince & Joy has its predictable side — but that doesn't mean that it lacks suspense. The skill with which the author delays the inevitable moment when the two main characters get together keeps the reader guessing as to the outcome right up to the end. And there are some well-observed vignettes of contemporary urban life, as well as a quartet of loveably eccentric flatmates to add zest to the mix.

Title: Welsh Book Festival
Full_text:
WELSH BOOK FESTIVAL
POETRY AND ROMANCE FROM
SIXTH CENTURY
FROM OUR OWN CORRESPONDENTr
o CARDIFF, FEB. 25
The Wclsh Book Festival, which has now reached its fifth year, w,as opened here yesterday afternoon by the Deputy Lord Mayor. The REv. GwILYMt DAVIES, chairman of the festival committee, presided, and among the speakers were Mr. H. Idris Bell, Keeper of Manuscripts at the British Museum, and Mr. W. P. Wheldon secretary, Welsh Department, Board of Education.
The theme of the exhibition this year is the poetry and romance of Wales from the Cynfeirldd, or the sixth-century Welsh poets, down to the present day, and the illustrative material, drawn from the collections in the Cardiff Public Library, embraces original manuscripts, facsimiles, printed works, and portraits. Among the exhibits in the Cynifeirdd section' are facsimiles of the "Black Book of Carmarthen" and the "Book of Taliesin," and dhc manuscript of the " Book of Aneirin," writteii about 1250, and containing the heroic song-of defeat, Y Gododditi, the first in importance of the early poems, and Gorchaitau. Facsimile reproductions of the " White Book of Rhydderch " and the " Red Book of Hergest," containing 11 of the Mabinogion romances, and two sixteenth-century versions of the story of Tristan and Essyllt and the " Historia of Peredur " are also shown, together wvith the English translation, by Lady Charlotte Guest, in three volumes. Modern illustrated editions of the Arthurian romance include the works of Aubrey Beardsley, W. Russell Flint, Arthur Rackham, Maurice Lalau, Evelyn Paul, and Willy Pogany.
The " Bruts," or Welsh chronicles, on view include Geoffrey of Monmouth's fabulous work, Historia Region Britainniae, a fourtecnthcentury manuscript of the Brut Tysilio, and the Brut Grufgydd ab Arthiur, a fifteenth-century manuscript, both written on vellum. Letters and manuscripts relating to nineteenth-century poets include' a notable group, at the head of which stood Ceiriog (John Hughes), the greatest lyrical writer of the century, and Islwyn (the Rev. William Thomas).
Concurrently with the festival is an exhibition of printed books, entirely set on the linotype, designed to show the advance made in fine printing in recent years.

NEW NOVELS
Among new novels are Mr. W. B. Maxwell's HIMsELF AND MR. RAIKES (Hutehinson, 7s. 6d. net) and Mir. Owen Rutter's LUcxY STAR (Hutchinson, 7s. 6d. net).
Mr. Maxwell, in treating of HnmsEr.
AND Mx. RA=Es, has developed one of those problems of personality into which he is occasionally -tempted. The result in this case is not quite so successful as on some earlier occasions. Oswald Raikes is one of those people who begin quite young to examine their own motives and take themselves very seriously in hand. He discovered, at 19, that he was insincere, and, further, that this insincerity had its roots in cowardice, physical and moral. Thenceforward he proceeded to fight these innate tendencies, continually choosing the harder way when alternatives were open to him, chastening his desires, following the road of self-sacrifice, and ineidentsJly becoming richer, more famous, and more respected by tEhe world at large. So far we seem to be on the verge of the usual admirible moral, but the fact is that we are left with the impression that Oswald Raikes has in some way missed the goal he set out to attain. We leave him regretfully deciding to recover from the effects of a severe accident, but are given no particular reason to hope that he will at last find the happiness Jae has so far mised.
Mr. Owen Rutter must have chosen his title, Lucxr STAR, with Mr. Harold Drake, Upper Shrimpton's efficient postmaster, in mind, for nobody else in IJpper Shrimpton except, perhaps, Bryan Grant and Stella Daker, w4o were so much in love that all places were precisely the same to them, thought it lucky to be on this part of the Essex coast on the Sunday evening and on an independent planet wheeling in space on the Monday morning. For Mr. Drake,who had a passionate hero-worship for his namesake 'of the "Golden' Hind," the situation was perfect, for while Drake could, at the best, only explore the seas and continents of earth, it was his unique
rivile e to explore a new planet. Apart from oronicling the delights and adventures of Mr. Drake, Mr. Rutter has taken the opportunity given him by the extraordinary fate of Uppejr Shrirpton-or Shrimpton-in-space as it became-to read a good-humoured thoulgh satirical- lecture on the truth that, although the sky may change, the mind does not. At any rate, most of the characteristics' of UJpper Shrimnpton in Essexc survived in Shrimpton-in-Space; but, although Mr. Butter makes his points with a proper relish, he does not allow satire to eclipSe the irresponsible amusement there is to be found in "Lucky Star."

Author: Null
Title: New Novels
Full_text:
NEWV NOVELS
Among new novels are SEVEN, BOBSwoRTn, by J. D. Beresford (Faber and Faber, 7s. 6d. net); EUROPA'S BEAST, by R. H. Mottram (Clhatto and Windus, 7s. 6d. net); and Our-oF STrP, by Derek W0talker Smnith (Gollanez, 7s. 6d. net).
Mr. J. D. Beresford gives us a sharp satire, but the point is softened a little by his constant sense of fun. Bobsworth was a garden city promoted by an ambitious financier, Sir James Cobbold, and a thrusting newvspaper proprietor, Lord Grout, both determined to reap for themselves t-he fruits of philantluopic notoriety. The name of the site was an initial sturmbling-block; Sir James wanted to call the citv " Elysium," but came to agree -with Lord Grout that "some of the other papers are sure to get hold of the right name and make a joke of it, say we're getting our Bobsworth or something, you understand ; and if that joke's going to be made, as he says it vwill, Ihis opinion is that we'd better make it ourselves to begin with and get it over." But a worse trouble was the invasion of the rising city at its top end by a swvarm of " cranks," holding strange faiths, practising strange diets, and wearing strange clothes, or, worse still, no clothes to spealc of at all. Bobsworth had to be purged, if respectability was to make a home there and rents to soar becomingly, so Mr. Fiddler, a journalist of few scruples, was sent to live among the " top-enders," at No. 7, Firstwvay, and inspire the campaign for fireezing them out. There follows a kind of burlesque epic, describing the war of the " top-enders " with the " desirable " tenants, the evolution of Bobsworth on lines of impeccable squareness (architectural and moral), and finally Mlr. Fiddler's heroic end amid the ruins of his mansion-a new enemy arrived after the War and wanted the land of No. 7 for industrial development. Mr. Beresford keeps up the joke wvith unfailing vivacity, and never lets it for a moment droop or turn to monotony.
MIr. R. H. Mottram's story resuscitates Geoffrey Skene, first known to us from " The Spanish Farm." It is not at first obvious what the fantastic title can have to do with so wortlly, so stoical, and so resignedly unsatisfied a man. About Skene's actions as architect to the municipal housing committee of Easthampton there is anything but a bull-like quality and in the end he is practically dismissed for paying too little attention to his work. The real reason, however, was that his attentions to Olive Blythway were too obvious to please her father, the chairman. We come 'to see that Skene's taurine capacities were only metaphorical, relating to Olive alone, and more passive
than active. Olive had been unsatisfac- l torily married: her young airmanhusband-a case of arrested development owving to wounds-had hardly roused her sleeping nature. Skene, fascinated by her exquisite line, senses in her the lVaiting Europa. M1r. Mottram, albeit with considerable deliberation, disposes of the husband as he had previously disposed of a coming baby. Skene carries off his widow Blythiway wvhen he finds her in a Cornish village: her surrender is lS perfect as Europa's in the Veronese picture that supplies the guiding image, lt is a pretty image, but the preparations for its cxhibition are rather laboured.
It is time another Pub]ic School novel was vritten, and the question in heavy black type on the jacket of Mr. D. W. Smith's story, "Have the post-War Public Schools 'learnt notling and forgotten nothing' ? " bas a certain pertinence. Mr. Derek Walk-er Smith answvers the question in a direct and an indirect way which flatly contradict each other. - " Yes," argues Mr. Smith directly, " they have learnt nothing and forgotten nothinga" for here is my hero, Colin, on page 231, after five years at Ormond, agreeing that the Public School systerm is designed to curb the spirit of the individual, but, up to page 231, Mfr. Smith has been busy showving how a determined and belligerent individualist like Colin can w%iD not only tolerance for himself but popularity. Colin, with his intellectual precosity, may have found many of the rules he was forced to keep irksome and paltry, but he was allowed to run the School Debating Society before he liad any position of authority even in his house, and hiis notion.that " in the opinion of this House, the 13ritish Empire has outlived its usefulness and should be disintegrated" -was lost by a imajoifity far sm1aller than he had expected. The truth is that, however, much Mr. Smith may hold up Colin as a rebel " aoing doNvn scornful against many spears," tlho spears were little more than toy lances, whlich do the useful work of pricking immature conceit. In spite of hirmself, in fact,- Mr. Smith has m-nade Colin the hero, not of a hopeless cause and a losing battle, but of a battle that has been already won, and on nearly every page, in the conversations on politics, in the descriptions of discussions with masters, in the comparative neglect of athletics, Ai'. Smith supplies evidence for tho conclusions he is so curiously uniwilling to draw.

Author: Craig, Amanda
Title: Children's History Books
Full_text:
review books
CHILDREN'S HISTORY BOOKS AMANDA CRAIG
L§m£J$mm*rLjfii4:i%i ■ M t"jV:
Embattled as we are by the unintelligent prescriptions of the national curriculum, we desperately need good history books. Yet while nonfiction is storming ahead with series such as Terry Deary's Horrible Histories, historical fiction has never regained the heights it achieved in the 1960s when books by Geoffrey Trease, Roger Lancelyn Green and Rosemary Sutcliffe made us all history boys and girls. One writer who is helping to fill the gap is Caroline Lawrence, whose Roman Mysteries series deserves its devoted following. The Colossus of Rhodes takes our quartet of multicultural detectives out of the city and across the sea towards Greece, into danger at the hands of a brutal slave-dealer. Though its dialogue lacks subtlety, it compensates with a lively, detailed knowledge of classical history. Eleanor Updale's burglarturned-gentleman, Montmorency, is now middleaged, and anxious for the safety of his friendls nephew, Frank. The rise of both trade
its pases c&mmi A MYSTERIOUS corse, a mmm of SENET AND tmm INFORgvUTION
unionism and the Mafia in Italy, England and America put the young aristocrat at the heart of a conspiracy in Montmorency and the Assassins, and he has to use every scrap of acting ability leamt from our hero to survive. A complex and satisfying thriller, its enjoyable features include advances in Victorian radiology, and the intertwining of real-life people such as Edison and Puccini with a fictional cast. There is even more derring-do with Michael Molloy's Peter Raven Under Fire, a Hornblower for youngsters that will make them experts on Napoleonic naval techniques in the wake of a terrific, rip-roaring adventure about slaves, piracy and the Caribbean. K. M. Grant's Green Jasper, the sequel to her excellent debut, Blood Red Horse, is set in the time of Richard the Lionheart. The crusades feature heavily in Key Stage 3 history, and this swashbuckling , romance about a kidnapped bride and a noble horse loved by both Christian and Muslim is a romping read.
For students of the Victorian era, Dorothy Edwards's A Strong and Willing Girl is also captivating It is based on her aunt's experiences of being in service as a 10-year-old in 1887, and displays an artless authenticity that charms. Of nonfiction books, Paul Dowswell's Introduction to the Second World War, written under the auspices of the Imperial War Museum, is superb. It lays out information in clear, vivid paragraphs, lavishly illustrated by dramatic, period photographs. The Battle of Britain, the defeat of Japan and the role of the Resistance are covered in detail, and the book offers recommendations for film and TV, plus valuable links to the internet Highly recommended. Book House has had the inspired idea of turning the lives of great leaders into graphic novels. Each has four pages of biographical overview, then plunges into Marvel comic-style action accounts of the lives of such figures as Queen Elizabeth I, Alexander, Julius Caesar, Hernan Cortes and Spartacus, with battles and murder looming large. It isn't Art Spiegelman, but an amazing amount of information is packed into this dramatic format, which will persuade reluctant junior historians to keep reading. The most enchanting history book of all, however, is Egyptology. Purporting to be the diaries of Miss Emily Sands, an archaeologist iri 1926, its pages contain a mysterious curse, a game of senet, fabulous foldouts and much information. The burnished gold cover, with its jewelled Horus, enthrals children even before they open it and fall in love with the past — which is what all history books should make us do, but seldom manage. The Colossus of Rhodes (9+) by Caroline Lawrence (Orion, £8.99; offer £7.64, call 0870 1608080). Montmorency and the Assass/ns (10+) by Eleanor Updale (Scholastic, £12.99; offer £10.39). Peter Raven Under Fire (10+) by Michael Molloy (Chicken House, £12.99; offer £10.39). Green Jasper (10+) by K. M. Grant (Puffin, £4.99; offer £4.24). A Strong and Willing Girl (9+) by Dorothy Edwards (Jane Nissen, £6.99; offer £5.94). Introduction to the Second Wor/d War (11+) by Paul Dowswell (Usborne, £12.99; offer £1039). Book House graphic nonfiction series (9+): Herna'h Cortes: The Life of a Spanish Conquistador; Elizabeth I: The Life ofEngand's Tudor Queen; Spartacus: The Life ofa Roman Gladiator; Julius Caesar: The Life of a Roman General; all £6.99 each, offer £5.94 each. Egyptology (7+) by Emily Sands, Templar, £17.99, offer £14.39

Author: J. S.
Title: New Novels
Full_text:
NEW NOVELS
ONE WITH A PLOT
THY LAMP, 0 MEMORY. By CosMo
HAMILTON. Hutchinson. 7s. 6d.
BALKAN EXPRESS. By LEONARD Ross.
Heinemann. 7s. 6d.
LEARN TO LOVE FIRST. By AMABEL
WILLIAMS-ELLIS. Gollancz. 7s. 6d.
LOVE IN THE SUN. By LEO WALMSLEY.
Collins. 8s. 6d.
What first attracts one's attention to Mr. Cosmo Hamilton's novel is his description of it. "A novel with a plot "-this is dircct and critical. There is evidently to be no shilly-shallying here, no marking time while the characters lose themselves deeper and deeper in the examination of the poor "unconscious," no disquisition on the political situation divided among half a dozen proxies for the author. On the contrary, things are going to move, and many causes will be shown to have their many effects. It is much more restful for the reader.
THY LAM.P, 0 MEMORY resembles Pinero's plays, in having a " situation." To understand this you are to imagine a prologue, in which a young girl of good family has the misfortune to have a baby and the good fortune to have a mother who takes the responsibility of disposing of the child. One can almost see the curtain falling as Dupont, the faithful French maid, whisks the infant off to be brought up in obscurity. Twenty-five years later the characters reassemble. The girl is now Mrs. Mandrey, a pleasant sort of woman who has had to turn her country house into a private hotel; the father is now a peer and something in Whitehall; and the bov plays the violin at the Dome in Montparnasse. The parents have long since put out of their minds the memory of a youthful indiscretion, but the violinist, who has just learnt the truth about | his parentage, is resentful and ready to
listen to the suggestion that he should ask for help. It is less theatrical and more interesting than it sounds. Mrs. Mandrey is not a villainess but an affectionate mother to her other son and a patient wife to a selfish husband. When her husband leaves her for a richer and more admiring woman she is not altogether sorry, and she settles again to the many problems before the proprietor of a genteel boarding house with an interest the reader can easily share. Though the plot is made the important thing, the accessories are unusual and not at all dull, and Mr. Hamilton has made of them all a book to while away several hours vcry agreeably.
A BALKAN INTRIGUE
On the pretext of choosing holiday reading we can be unusually indulgent to a frivolous taste. There is seldom space to spare for such unpretentious entertainmnent as the adventure story, but BALKAN EXPRESS may be recommended without apology. To say that the book would make an entertaining film is not to disparage it. For an hour's amusement with enthusiastic foreign correspondents, international intrigue, rapid journeys, and resourceful. impudence nothing could be better, and Mr. Leonard Ross has written his adventure with a proper brevity. One can see the film advancing as one reads. One sees the talented correspondent tearing himself away from the office in order Ito celebrate his engagement and five [minutes later abandoning the party on a chase after news in the Balkans; one sees l the flight to intercept the train at inns-
bruck, the search along the whole train for the Prince and Princess on the way to restoration, the pursuit across Vienna, and then another aeroplane and another capital. That is the way it goes, and it goes very excitingly. A revolution follows, then evasion of arrest, then the lighthearted resolution of an engagement no longer attractive. All is swift, gay, and so persuasive that one finds oneself preparing to catch a train to the country as though it were another of these fascinating international expresses.
Another novel about revolution on | the Continent is LEARN TO LOVE IFIsr, a romantic and sometimes, in Ithe nature of things, rather unpleasant !tale of a young man who discovers
that his marriage is only one of convenience and that his wife is the Dictator's mistress. It is a book in which I inequalities and changes of mood are fre-
quent. At times Miss Amabel WilliamsEllis treats us to some romantic sentiment on the part of the wife that belongs to another kind of fiction; at others she is making a serious attempt to analyse the state of mind of an idealist whose eyes !have just been opened to the true character
of a man whom he revered and loved. The action, which is swift and not unexciting, takes place in a State not precisely identified, but one in which conditibns are familiar to anyone who reads the foreign news. It is, at any rate, a dependency of the Reich, but its internal politics are its own. Though there are repressive laws for those who disagree with the Government, all the elements of revolution are present, and opportunity is not long in coming. The revolutionaries have. scarcely completed their organization when the lady, who begins to. regret her wasted marriage, removes their most dangerous opponent.
THE HAPPY DEBTOR
To this LoVE IN THE SUN makes a cheerful contrast. It is a novel about happy people, people who sometimes fancy they are in trouble and discover before long that their enemies were only fancied and are in fact good friends. The narrator and the girl he means to marry when he has his divorce find a cabin on a Cornish estuary and set up house. A piece of land and a stretch of shore go with the cabin, and the real story is the development of house and land into a pleasant and much-loved property. The beginnings are small, since the narrator is in hiding from his creditors up in Yorkshire and has only a few pounds and no prospect of more. They buy a few things and are presented with more from an idle yacht-
builder's down the estuary; They saw and hammer, convert jetsam (or flotsam) to useful purposes, adopt a stray kitten, make a garden, build a dinghy into a motorboat, marry, and produce a child called Amelia. And what do they live on all this; time ? The rewards of collecting insects and small creatures for the scientists, and the promise of a book on which the narrator is working. It is a charming story, if a trifle ingenuous. Though we may regard the people as nothing more than the excuse for an account of a fascinating enterprise that will be appreciated by all who have a garden or a country cottage or a boat of their own, or wish for these things, it is almost an advantage in such a book. Since the troubles are not convincing enough to cast a real gloom there is nothing to sDoil an
enviable undertaking.
J. S.

Author: Campling, Chris
Title: Choice
Full_text:
CHOICE CHRIS CAMPLING
BOOK OF THE WEEK: 31 SONGS Radio 4,9.45am/12.30am When I was in my teens , one of my friends compiled a weekly Top Ten of his favourite tunes. I presume he grew out of it Nick Hornby (right), on the other hand, carried his list-making into adulthood, even turning it into a bestselling book High Fidelity, and now 31 Songs, from which he reads all this week. The difference between my friend and Hornby is that the former was content merely to list the songs;
the latter actually explains why these 31 songs mean so much to him, not apparently, the sentimental reasons, but the music itself. And being one hell of a writer, he explains himself so much better than did my friend who, on being asked why Lay/a was still at the top after 17 weeks , said: "Well , I like it the most" THE SCIENCE OF DIY Radio 4,3.45pm Hurray, two of my blind spots in one programme! Len Fisher, too, was
something of a DIY disaster area — until , that is, he brought his day job to bear. For Fisher, the son of a carpenter , is a physicist and by applying his scientific training he assures us that , in theory at any rate , he is now a right little Handy Andy . This first programme deals with wheelbarrows; tomorrow he moves on to chisels and saws, then hammers and nails. By Friday even the clumsiest among us will no doubt be able to knock up a virtual cocktail cabinet
INSIDE THE CROWN PROSECUTION SERVICE . Radio 4, 8pm After the collapse of several high - profile cases the Crown Prosecution Service (CPS) is right up there with Social Services in the "couldn't organise drinky-poohs in a brewery" stakes. Boldly, though, the Essex CPS invited the tape-recorders in to observe it at work, giving us the opportunity to hear actual cases being prosecuted. Intriguing stuff from inside the law.

Len Fisher, too, was something of a DIY disaster area until , that is, he brought his day job to bear. For Fisher, the son of a carpenter , is a physicist and by applying his scientific training he assures us that , in theory at any rate , he is now a right little Handy Andy . This first programme deals with wheelbarrows; tomorrow he moves on to chisels and saws, then hammers and nails. By Friday even the clumsiest among us will no doubt be able to knock up a virtual cocktail cabinet INSIDE THE CROWN PROSECUTION SERVICE . Radio 4, 8pm After the collapse of several high profile cases the Crown Prosecution Service (CPS) is right up there with Social Services in the "couldn't organise drinky poohs in a brewery" stakes. Boldly, though, the Essex CPS invited the tape recorders in to observe it at work, giving us the opportunity to hear actual cases being prosecuted. Intriguing stuff from inside the law.

Author: Null
Title: New Novels
Full_text:
NEW -r NOVELS
Among new novels are ROYAL FLUSH: The Story of Minette, by Margaret Irwin (Chatto and Windus. 8s. 6d. net); and THANK HEAVEN F.ASTING, by E. Al. Delafield (Macmillan, 7s. 6d. net).
MIiss Alargaret Irnin's new historical novel is at once a faithful reconstruction
of historical scenes and a delightful story. | It is also one of the rare modern books in wvhich the charm of the House of Stuart is made apparent without being sentimentalized. Good Roundheads of the school of John Richard Green may refuse to admit that the picture of Charles II. is true to life, but even they will acknowledge that it is brilliant and persuasive. The same may be said, if in some cases the portraits are slighter, of all the Royal figures in Miss Irwin's " Royal Flush." The heroine is Charles's youngest sister, Henrietta, who was married to Philip of Orleans, younger brother of Louis XIV., and whose beauty, sweetness, capriciousness, and keen political brain are so often talked of in French memoirs of her tiine. The more one has read of her the more one is convinced that this is no mere facile, romantic portrait, but a remarkable recreation, and that Miss Irwin has got as close to the real woman as anyone is ever likely to do. The book is tragic, as must be the stozy of a girl brought up in exile after her father had died by the hand of his own subjects, married to a degenerate whlile in love with his great brother, and dying at the age of twenty-six, not knowing in her last hours wlhetlher or not she had been poisoned at the instance of her husband or one of his minions. Yet it has gaiety, as Minette had.
In THANK HEAVEN FASTING Miss E. M.
Delafield studiously presents to our attention the young society girl who grew up wlhen petticoats were worn and daughters drank hot milk in mamma's bedroom after a ball and were sent to lie down all afternoon before they went out at night. They tvere an obedient. sheeplike, anxious lot, with but one idea-to get married. Mlen were " quite good " or " no use at all," and when one of them was any good, mamma and daughter beguiled and coaxed hin and with luck landed him safely at the altar. Miss Delafield takes a small social group to dissect and ponder over, and of course she does it with sparkling competence and sound knowledge. From the skin out she vividly describes every stitch that the welldressed young women of pre-War days (Edwardian days indeed) put on for various social occasions. She is acutely entertaining. She is even better when shc shows us the minds and hearts beneath the drapery and lets us listen to the maiden's prayer for a man, a marriage and perhaps a son. Her limp heroine, Monica, and her limper friends, evoke pity and a writlhing dismay for the hard path that women used to tread. MIiss Delafield has given us an excellent and amusing document, bitterly truthful, whlich shows us vivid pictures of the not far distant past when to be 25 and unmarried (if female) was to be a disgrace to one's parents and a confessed failure. Her book is extremely entertaining, althouglh she never slackens the current of Monica's anxiety until the altar and the last line are reached.

Title: New Novels
Full_text:
NEW NOVELS.
JOYOUS FOOLING.
6TRAss RELAioNs. By CyRri ALING-
TON. (Macmillan. 6s. net.)
A young Baronet, who must be carefully dissociated from the usually iniqui. tous members of that Order so often to be met in fiction, is enamoured of a young American, and, in order to induce her mother, Mrs. Branson, to visit him, with her daughter, in the country, invents a mysterious clairvoyant Professor to minister to her desire to communicate with her deceased husband. A married sister who was to have. played hostess fails, and the Baronet, determined not to disappoint his American guests, persuades an unmarried cousin to impersonate the missing sister.
More, solicitous for the susceptibilities of Mrs. Branson, who is an ardent disciple of Pussyfoot, the Baronet insists on hustling an avuncular brewer into the unpremeditated part of a retired Indian civilian, regardless of his relative's unhappy ignorance both of the geography of India and of the habits of the natives of that Finpire. Not content with this, Mr. Alington makes a noble lord, in a quixotic desire to defend his twin brother's disparaged name, assume his clerical identity and burden himself with a teetotalism wholly foreign to his tastes. The company assembles, and even Sir Charles Hawtrey would find it difficult to reach the high level of improvisation required to deceive al the guests all the time. Lady Mary, desperately playing hostess and mother alike, is faced with Mhrs. Branson's inexhaustible curiosity as to the numbers, names, ages, sexes, and. weights at birth of her putative faiiyfacts about which she is so ill-informed that when confronted with some photographs which inconveniently represent children wholly different from those that she has been descrtbing, she is almost compelled to surrender.
The noble lord flounders rather in descnrbing a parish he has never visited and recounting duties he has never performed, but, when pushed, is more circumstantially mendacious than the brewer, who in an agony to find the line of least resistance asserts that he is chldlless. The complications become almost unbearable, the unhappy impostors almost have to lie to themselves and practise deception in their sleep, and as a last straw the Baronet learns of the proximate arrival of the real curate-twin and of the two sons of the brewer whose existence had been denied by the inexperienced maiidacity of their distracted parent.
Great Jove was'known to nod in days when he set the fashion, and there is good authority for the saying, Sem7per non tendit arnm ApoRo,. so, in turing aside from his Playing Fields and "Holy Shade" into the gentle paths of laughter, the EHeadmaster of Eton does but set the seal of authoritative approval upon a mythological precedent for which aUl readers of the pages which he has filled with delightful and joyous fooling wil be most gratefuL
