Author: J. S.
Title: New Novels
Full_text:
NEW NOVELS I THE URBANE COMEDY
PERSONAL EFFECTS. By BARBARA WILLARD.
Macmillan. 7s. 6d.
CALL THE TUNE. By BARBARA GOOLDEN.
Heinemann. 7s. 6d.
THE SHEPHERD'S FARM. By ADRIAN BELL.
Cobden-Sanderson. 7s. 6d.
THE HEROES. By MILLEN BRAND. Cassell.
7s. 6d.
THE WORLD OWES ME A LIVING. By JOHN
LLEXVELYN RHYS. Faber and Faber. 7s. 6d.
Some books are written to please. Odd as it may seem, this is a fact of which we need to be reminded. What with being lectured and having our consciences roughly disturbed-for our own good and at a price-and our sense of humour abomninably underrated by anyone who can hit on a farcical notion, it is very easy to forget it. Often the lecturers and the missioners-but not the farce-writersare plausible and accomplished enough to draw one's admiration; but admiration is not the whole of enjoyment. A reader needs besides to laugh and like and never suspect that while he reads he improves himself. Chance this week has brought out several novels of a kind that grows increasingly uncommon. They neither break our hearts nor shamelessly pick our pockets, but they amuse and stimulate. It is a courtesy to the reader that more than justifies the pains their authors took with them. To please, stimulate, and amuse it is not necessary to have an entirely new idea.
We know already the situation of the surprising will on which Miss Barbara Willard's PERSONAL EFFECTS is built up. There is nothing novel in the scene in which the Sansoms sit back comfortably to hear how father has done his duty by them, only to find that father's sense of humour has once more been too strong. Yct of thesz Miss Willard makes something fresh, lively, and engrossing. Even the younger generation of Sansoms is capable on occasion of the lack of humour that sometimes goes with a sense of the importance of family and position; and there could hardly be a better corrective than the discreet amusement of the new heir. Richard Elder was old Sansom's posthumous surprise, and the fact that he works, and enjoys working, and is not unduly impressed with his good fortune doubles his advantage over his new relatives. Apart from noting the effect of the will on the various members of the family, we have also to watch the interesting situation of Miss Kay Sansom, her cousin Stephen, a flirtatious and independable young man, who is capable of much unintentional harm, her cousin Ruth, who is young enough beneath her manner to take him seriously, and young Elder, who is dependable without being dull. As for the writing, it is as urbane as the comedy.
THREE SISTERS
CALL THE TUNE is rather more serious, but it displays much the same kind of ironical humour. Again it is a family, but in this case a family broken by the death ot' the mother, to whom Irene in particular was devoted. Greta has her elderly adored husband, and Lettice, the second sister, a little boy for whom she neglects his father. Each has her own form of idolatry, for which her sisters pity her, and Miss Barbara Goolden's task has been to show the various tests to which these engrossing loves may be put. For all her humour, for instance, Irene is inclined at times to be earnest, especially in the matter of falling in love. There is a bearded and sarcastic revolutionary who attracts her and annoys her relatives, and there is alsoamelancholy,unthinking Civil servant home on leave who hopes for a charming, frustrated, and satisfactorily sentimental friendship. The time is the very recent, with private affairs necessarily ovcrshadowed by international uncertainty, and Miss Goolden manages to give a lively account of divergent opinions and the various responses made to recurrent crises. She is successful above all in allowing her people free play, so that the book ends naturally with Irene decided and her sisters not greatly changed, except for a little more experience.
A delightful book of a very different k-ind is Mr. Adrian Bell's THE SHEPHERD'S FARM, which is full of the countrvman's immense lore and industry. Though the people are interesting enough, the real principals are the fields and farm animals, which are shown us over a period of 40 years. By care and wise planning. the shepherd obtains his farm from his former master, and most of an absorbing story deals with his gradual developments and improvements on it. The girl he marries is of yeoman stock and tired of doing nothing but hunt and dance when she has once had a taste of hard work as deputy for her father, the squire's agent. It is largely her capital that buys the farm, and in the early days she has her fill of work in the dairy and beside her husband in the fields. The chronicle of sowing apd harvest, marketing, and white winters, and country diversions is fuller than a stranger might expect, and few people show Mr. Bell's ability to write about it with knowledge and affection.
AFTER THE WAR
Mr. Millen Brand, who wrote a very good first novel in " The Outward Room." now writes of life in a soldiers' home in America. THE HEROES is a short, restrained, and touching study of hope and hopelessness in a small section of the unemployed. The motive is always the distinction between home and the Home, to which these men, all more or less disabled, come reluctantlv only when it is impossible to keep themselves outside. The Home is not in itself unbearable. The men are individuals and as free as men can be when lack of money or work gives them long, empty days. When they car find work in the seasonal rushes of the factories they leave until the work stops,
but most of them come back. Not all the characters are as clear-cut as they might be, but that of the principal figure, a man whose meeting with a factory girl in the town gives him an added incentive to find work and a privatc life again, is drawn simply and effectively.
The community in THE WORLD OWES ME A LIVING is very much narrower, being a group of young men with their appendants who earn their living in a flying circus. They are bold, loud. hard-drinking, arrogantly " hcarty " young men with a contempt for very nearly everything that is not among their extremely limited interests. The fact that they are continually in danger of breaking their necks entitles them, in their own view, to consideration as more than usually intelligent and exciting persons. Title: New Novels
Full_text:
NEW NOVELS
THANK YOU, JEEVES. By P. G. WODE-
HOUSE. (Jenkins. 7s. 6d. net.)
One thinks of the world of Mr. Wodehouse as being perfect, and therefore stable-a world in which there is no change nor need for change. It comes, therefore, as a shock to read in the publishers' note to his new book that Jeeves has been translated from his sphere of the short story; it is " the first long story in which the prince of gentlemen's gentlemen has played the leading r6le." There is a further and more disintegrating shock in the first chapter; it is headed "Jeeves gives Notice," and for a moment it leads the reader to fear that there is an end to his association with his employer, Mr. Bertram Wooster. But this can hardly be, as it is Mr. Wooster who tells the story. Nor is it. As to that story it must suffice to say that it takes us back to the world already referred to, for action in that world is communicable only in the words of its creator, Mr. Wodehouse. As to the further question whether Jeeves is more Jeevesian in a long story than in a short, the point is, as Mr. Wooster might say, pretty moot. The ending is doubly happy; happy for the lovers, for about the last thing we learn of the leading lady is that " she remained in Chuffy's arms gurgling like a leaky radiator", and happy for the reader, for the last thing we learn of Jeeves is that he has re-entered the service of Mr. Wooster.
THE PADRE OF ST. JACOB'S. By STEPHEN
GRAHAM. (Nicholson and Watson. 7s. 6d. net.)
In his latest book Mr. Graham tells the story of the Rev. Mark Whyte, rector of a fashionable chapel, who has made himself notorious by Fleet Street activities and by conducting a substitute for the marriage service for divorced people. Mark is a strange mixture of guile and innocence, and when Gar Lloyd, a reputed ex-millionaire and gaol-bird, is converted by his ministry, the Padre and the whole of his entourage of church ladies and hangers-on believe in Lloyd's tale of the vast fortune he wants to bestow on the Padre. The end of the story is obvious almost from the first chapter, but that does not detract from its interest. Mr. Stephen Graham creates a group of characters, most of them with just that little rottenness at the core, a touch of self-interestedness combined with dilettantism, which makes them ready victims for such as Gar Lloyd. If any of the characters had been sincere and honest the book would have been depressing; as it is, it provides amusement of a rather bitter type.

Title: New Novels
Full_text:
-NEW NOVELS
DE VRIENDT GOES HOME. By ARNOLD
ZWEIG. Translated from the German by ERIc SuTroN. (Heinemann. 7s. 6d. net.)
The theme of Herr Zweig's novel is the politics of Zionism and the relation of Jew and Arab in Palestine to-day. He has brought to it passionate feeling and a marked degree of impartiality, and he has succeeded in creating out of it a story of fine tragic sensibility. The de Vriendt of the title is a Dutch Jew, a scholar and a poet, who has come to the Holy Land almost entirely for reasons of piety and who is completely hostile to the secularization of Jewry and the nationalist aims of the Zionist cause. The story opens in July, 1929, when the dispute between the Jews and the Arabs over the WVailing Wall is reaching a dangerous point of tension. Author: Wood, Christopher
Title: New Books
Full_text:
NEW BOOKS A guide to the gay world and a memoir on the last hours of Hitler are an eclectic mix for Christopher Wood
THE BENT LENS by Lisa Daniel and Claire Jackson, Roundhouse, £9.99 UNTIL THE FINAL HOUR by Traudl Junge, Phoenix, £7.99 THE 19th London Lesbian and Gay Film Festival wrapped up this week, but for those already itching for the 20th, consolation comes with The Bent Lens, an encyclopaedia of what some critics call "queer cinema". In fact, this new edition of The Bent Lens takes account of a further development: "new queer cinema", whose advent was noted by an ever-alert critical fraternity in 1992. The encyclopaedia's remit is broad, covering both films where sexuality is the central theme and those where it is more tangential. American Beauty is there for its male kiss — although the bits I was awake for suggested that its main argument was something else. And then there are films such as the wonderful American comedy But I'm a Cheerleader, about a holiday camp to which parents send their children for the correction of early signs of homosexuality, where gayness is the core subject of the film.
Going back in time, in movies as in other art forms, coyness, obliqueness or symbolism were unavoidable for the representation of gay themes. In the Sixties, mainstream movies were just about out of the closet, with films such as V7ct/m, The Children's Hour and The Killing of Sister George. But before that, social pressures^ when dealing with the love that dare not speak its name resulted in such bizarre artefacts of high camp as Nicholas Ray's kinky western Johnny Guitar, where Marlboro Country offers something quite different from your average swarthy, cigarette-puffing hero. The Bent Lens also tries to out certain films that I would never have suspected qf harbouring such tendencies — John Ford's The Long Voyage Home for one. A much better candidate would have been Hitchcock's Rebecca, in which Laurence Olivier is camper than a row of tents and Mrs Danvers's feelings for her late mistress are clearly not the usual ones between a housekeeper and her employer. Or maybe they are. Who knows what really goes on in our country houses? Those who have seen the film Downfall, currently doing the rounds, may want to look
at the memoir it is loosely based on, Until the Final Hour by Traudl Junge. She was Adolf Hitler's secretary from November 1942 until her employer shot himself in April 1945, and was present in the bunker in Berlin when he did it. Downfall, despite being in German, will probably reach a wider public, but it is Junge's apparently artless memoir that provides the subtler and more perceptive portrait of the seductiveness of Nazism — written by someone who was herself seduced, and was racked with guilt over it right up to her death in 2002. For one thing it was written in 1947, before reactions to the Nazi experience had been channelled into their prescribed forms. In the film we see Hitler on the edge of reason, twitching, ranting, arbitrarily arresting and appointing, flailing, foundering and foaming. No one could easily be taken in by such a grotesque apology for a human being. The Hitler Junge encountered, however, was a model employer — correct but informal, courteous and gentlemanly. It is as well to remember that the worst people sometimes have the best manners.
